div.head: TO HER GRACE THE Dutchess of BOLTON.
div.p: WHen the Curious hand of Nature draws Perfection, when Beauty like yours appears, all are inspired with Wonder and Delight, every Heart is filled with Pleasure, because every Heart is full of you; Pardon my Ambition, Pardon the daring of a Pen, too weak to Coppy inimitable Graces; but if none may aim at your lovely Picture, unless they have Power to do you Justice, your Praises must be left unsung, and you for ever adored in Silence.

I own the following Play claims not the least Merrit to such a Glorious Protection, but that is all I have to boast, all the reward my Towring Fancy covets, is centred in my Illustrious Patronesses; this will to after Ages make my Trifle Sacred, when they behold prefix'd such Names, whose Virtues Historians, Poets, and never dying Fame shall join with me to Eternize.

The Play is partly a Translation from the French; what I added, if it had not the power to please, had no Immodesty to offend, which I hope will be an attonement with your Grace, for other Defects in my Younger Brother; I wou'd have perswaded the World to prize Desert, before the Gifts of Fortune, but the major part are too sordid to like the Example, few are so truly Noble to fix without Intrest, which makes so very few truly happy in their Choice.

I wou'd have deferr'd Addressing to Your Grace, till I had aimed at an Offering more Worthy, but my Charmed Eyes being lately bless'd with the sight of You, have let into my mind such a Beautiful Idea, that I liv'd in pain till I express'd my Admiration.

To be Great and Good, and Exquisitly Fair, are the happiest Epethets Fate bestows on Mortals; that they are justly Your Graces due▪ will, I am sure, be confirmed by an Universal Voice; and that you may Live long to adorn the Titles, whose Lustre receive addition from that Beauteous Fame, is the Eternal wish off

closer.signed: Your Graces, most humble, and most Obedient Servant, Mary Pix.

div.head: PROLOGUE Spoke by Mr. Bowman.
div.l: YOur Servant Ladies fair— And how I pray,
Like you my Dress and Garniture to Day.
'Faith I've survay'd my self from Top to Toe,
And find I make a most Accomplish'd Beau.
If all these Charms, to win a Fortune fail,
I'le leave Champagne, and drown my shape in Ale;
What care I if I'm bigger than a Whale?
But why should I despair of being Blest.
Can Female Heart withstand a Man thus Drest?
As I was lately Walking in the Mall,
Heav'ns! how the Ladies flock'd about me all.
I'le vow they came so Termagantly Fierce on,
I fear'd some strange designs upon my Person.
Says one, and faith the Nymph was well enough,
Mind, with what Air and Grace he takes his Snuff,
The second cry'd, and pray observe his Muff.
My Sword-Knot charm'd the fancy of the third,
Poor simple thing she scarce cou'd speak a Word.
And, I replies the fourth, Alass! am Slain,
With the Celestial motion of his Cane.
The Fifth was strangely smitten with my shape;
Nay hold, I cried, you wont commit a Rape?
For mine, and for your own dear sakes be quiet,
Or Ladies I'le endite you for a Riot.
But hold— there's something I was begg'd to say,
In favour of our modest Authors Play.
He hop'd you'd like— but Ha! the Bird is Flown,
No matter, I'le say something of my own.
Know then, our Comedy first came from France,
Which here perhaps, its Fortune may advance.
Ladies, be you as kind as you are pretty,
And you Gallants as merciful as Witty:
Then may both Stage and Poet hope to thrive,
Tis by your Bounty both are kept alive.

div.head: EPILOGUE Spoken by a Boy.
div.l: CUstome in England makes poor Poet scrape,
In hopes by that Damnation to escape.
But we our Plot have fetch'd from Foreign Nation,
And there such scraping is no ver good Fashion.
Therefore our Author arm'd with French Assurance,
No Pardon Asks, and owns no ill performance.
But hither sends me à la mode de France,
Messieurs & Dames, to treat you with a Dance.
After the Dance.
Ma foi,— taking Breath.
I have exhausted quite ma respiration,
To please the Ladies, sur ma reputation.
I'de please the Fair, tho' I were sure of Dying,
I hope I have not strain'd my back with Trying.
Come then ye Beaux, your gayest Smiles put on.
'Twill spoil those dear bewitching looks to Frown.
Alass, why should you your ill nature show?
Starving of us, will nere advavantage you.
A Dam' sell once attack'd by Flesh and Blood,
By this one Argument her Spark withstood;
You'l ruin me, and do your self no good.
Then let our Theatre your favour find,
'Tis for your Honour, Gallants, to be kind.

div.head: ACT I. SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Rich with Betty, her Maid.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: WHat's the matter, Madam? What has happen'd to you? What has any body done to you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: An Affront? ... Ah! I die: An affront! ... I faint: I cannot speak. A Chair quickly.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: [Giving a Chair.] An affront! to you, Madam, an affront! Is it possible!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: But too true, my poor Betty. Oh! I shall dye. To disrespect me in the open Street! What Insolence!

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: How, Madam! Not to show respect to such a person as you? Madam Rich; the Widow of an honest Banker, who got Two Hundred Thousand Pounds in the King's service? Pray, Madam, who has been thus insolent?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: A Dutchess; who had the confidence to thrust my Coach from the Wall, and make it run back above twenty yards.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: A very impertinent Dutchess. What! Madam, your person shining all o're with Jewels, your new gilt Coach, your dappl'd Flanders with long Tails, your Coachman with cocking Whiskers like a Swiss Guard, your six Footman cover'd with Lace more than any on a Lord-Mayor's day? I say, could not all this imprint some respect in the Dutchess?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Not at all. And this beggarly Dutchess, at the end of an old Coach, drawn by two miserable starv'd Jades, made her tatter'd Footmen insult me.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: S'life! where was Betty. I'd have told her what she was.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: I spoke to her with a meen and tone proportionable to my Equipage; but she, with a scornful smile, cry'd, hold thy peace, Citizen, struck me quite dumb.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Citizen! Citizen! To a Lady in a gilt Coach, lin'd with crimson Velvet, and hung round with a gold Fringe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: I swear to thee, that I had not the force to answer to this deadly Injury; but order'd my Coachman to turn, and drive me home a full gallop.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: But, Madam, pray consider things rightly, and take this as it was intended; for, I conceive, it was not against your Person, but your Name, that this Affront was design'd; and why do you not make haste to change it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: That I have resolv'd; but I quarrel daily with my Destiny, that I was not at first a Woman of Quality.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Well, well, Madam, you have no great reason to complain; and tho' you are not as yet a Woman of Quality, you are at least very rich; and you know, that with money you may buy Quality, but Birth very often brings no Estate.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: That's nothing; there is something very charming in Quality, and a great Name.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p:
Yet sure you'd think your self in a worse condition, Madam, were you, as many great Ladies in the World are, who want every thing; and, in spight of
their great Name, are known, but by the great number of Creditors, that are bawling at their Doors from morning till night.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: That's the modish Air, 'tis that distinguishes the People of Quality.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Methinks, Madam, 'tis a great satisfaction, to dare to go out at the great Gate, without being in danger of having your Coach and Horses seiz'd by a troop of Serjeants: What wou'd you say, if you were oblig'd to return home in a filthy Hack, as several of Quality have done?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Ah! would to Heavens, that had happen'd to me, and that I were a Countess.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: But, Madam, you don't imagine—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I do imagine, and I had rather be the beggarliest Countess in the Town, than the Widow of the richest Banker in Europe. Well, I am resolv'd; and, I will be a Countess, cost what it will; and to that intent, I'll absolutely break all commerce with those little Cits, by whose Alliance I am debas'd; and first I'll begin with Mr. Rich.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Mr. Rich, Madam, your Brother-in-Law?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: My Brother-in-Law! my Brother-in-Law! thou simple Wench! prythee know better!

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Pardon me, Madam, I thought he had been your Brother-in-Law, because he was Brother to your Deceas'd Husband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: That's true, my Husband's Brother, but my Husband being Dead, Fool, Mr. Rich is now no more Kin to me than my Footman; nevertheless the Fellow thinks himself of Importance, and is continually a censuring my Conduct, and controuling my Actions: Nay, even the little Minx his Daughter, when we go in my Coach together, places her self at the end by my side.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Little ridiculous Creature!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: But that which Anger's me the most, is, that with her little smiling, mimicking Behaviour, she attracts the Eyes of the whole Town, and I have not so much as a Glance.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: What a Foolish Town is this! because she's young and pretty, they take more notice of her than you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: It shall be otherwise, or I'll see her no more.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Nay, your Ladyship will Humble her, for of late you rarely suffer her to come near you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Well, I will have a Title, and a Name, that's resolv'd; a Name that shall fill the Mouth.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Ah! Madam, a great Name will become you extreamly; but a Name is not sufficient, I believe you must have a Husband too; and you ought to take care what choice you make.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: I know the World well enough, and have in my Eye one of the most Accomplish'd Gentlemen in the Town.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: How, Madam, already made your choice, and I know nothing?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Sir John would not let me tell thee.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: What, Sir John? Sir John Roverhead of Roverhead Castle?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: He himself.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Why, Madam, speak seriously, is it Sir John Roverhead you design to Marry?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Prythee where's the wonder?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Why pray consider, Madam, Sir John is not worth a Groat.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: I have sufficient for us both, and there is Justice in what I design. Mr. Rich did not get his Estate too honestly; and 'tis some kind of Restitution, to raise up with what he has left me, one of the Ancients Families in the North.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Oh! since 'tis a Marriage of Conscience I have no more to say.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Betty.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Prythee what's thy Sirname.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Has your Ladyship forgot.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Dost imagine it worth a place in my memory?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Cork, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Oh, filthy! from henceforth let me call thee de la Bett; that has and Air French, and agreeable.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: What you please, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: De la Bett, whatever Bills the Mechanical fellows, little Trades people bring ye, let 'em wait, let 'em Walk for't, and watch my Lever, but if Monsieur comes that brought the prohibited Gloves, l'eau de fleur d'Orange, and the Complexion, you understand me, give him his price, and ready Money.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: And do ye hear, put a Hundred Guineas in the Embroider'd Purse for Bassett.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Bless me, Madam! have you lost all that I put in yesterday Morning?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Impertinence! I am sufficiently recompenc'd in Learning the Game, and the Honourable Company I am admitted into.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Indeed, Madam, the Footmen say, Mrs. Trickwell is a perfect Female Rook, lives upon Gaming, nay, and keeps out on't, they say, and they can tell.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, she is a Woman of Quality, knows every body at Court, all their Intrigues, is as deep in Affairs, and keeps as many Secrets, as Maintenon, I'll be sworn; ma foie. What a word was there! But, as I was saying, she has told me, and half a dozen Ladies more, Secrets six hours together; and such Secrets, de la Bett, let me die, were we not Women of discretion, might reach the Lives, or eternally disgrace, of some that shall be nameless.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: They are very happy, if they are in her power.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Peace, has no body sent a How-de-yee yet?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: 'Tis my horrid Custom of getting up fo early in a morning.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Madam, 'tis past Twelve.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: And I drest, and have been abroad, Abominable! I charge yee to morrow don't bring my Cloaths till past Two, if I am so mad to call for 'em.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Wont your Ladyship inquire after my Lady Landsworth's health, methinks you neglect her, tho' she is rich, gay and beautiful, and honours your House with her choice of it whilst she's in Town.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Honours! Who art thou speaking to, Sweet-heart? I do not like her, she wont play; nay, will sit ye two hours together and speak ill of no body; she is not fit for the conversation of Quality.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Madam, Mrs. Trickwell, and another Lady, is come to teach your Ladyship, Shombring, I think they call it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Ombre, Sot, I shall be rid of thee, thou fragment of the shop. De la Bett I'll go to them, if Sir John comes, call me, not else.

sp.speaker: Lansworth.
sp.p: My dear Mrs. Betty, I'm glad to find thee alone.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Your Ladyship does me too much honour.

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: Thou art so discreet and obliging, I cannot love thee too well. Where's thy impertinent Mistress?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Gone to learn Ombre, with a hundred Guinea's in her pocket.

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, her pride, ill nature, and Self-opinion, makes her Follies unpitty'd. I'de fain be rid of the nauseous conversation this House abounds with.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Indeed my City Lady turning Courtier, has a hopeful stock of Teachers; Mistresses grown old, and then forsaken, who, in the tatters of their Prosperity, pass upon her for decay'd Quality, Female Gamsters, and Fools in abundance.

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: They are affected without beauty, or good cloths, tho' that alone's enough to spoil one that had both; their mirth is insipid, and their raillery abusive, and yet not poinant. For my part, I've almost lost my gay humour for fear of being like 'em; if I continue here one Week longer I shall 'en exchange the Town, where I expected such pleasure, for my old Yorkshire retirement.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Cou'd you but get Mrs. Clerimont to ye, Madam, she'd immediately introduce you to the Beau Monde, where Wit, Gallantry, and good Breeding, are emulators. You say she's a Relation.

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: She is so at a distance, but you see all mysending will not prevail with her to come at me, nor appoint a time when I shall wait upon her; what can be the reason?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I know not, unless 'tis being here; for truly I fancy, tho' my Mistress is fled to Covent Garden, she is as much despis'd by the real Quality, as she is cajol'd by the Pretenders to it. You say you are not acquainted with Mrs. Clerimont tho' related to her: So perhaps she guesses you of our Stamp, and avoids yee. For Heavens sake, Madam, how came yee hither?

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: Why, I'll tell thee, Betty, I was married a meer Baby to a very old Man, who, in his Youth, having been a Debauchee, and dealing only with the worst of our Sex, had an ill Opinion of all, kept me like a Nun, broke off all commerce to London, or indeed with any body, not excepting Relations.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: And cou'd you indure this?

sp.speaker: Lady Landsworth,
sp.p: Most patiently; never found fault with his Woollen Shirts or Night Caps, lay all Night to the Musick of his Cough, or the ratling of his Ptisick, writ nothing but Receipts, scarce ever open'd my Mouth, but out came, how do ye do, my dear; did the Sirrup I made last please ye?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Your Ladyship was a Miracle.

sp.speaker: L. Landsworth.
sp.p: And what do you think I got by doing thus?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I don't know, but I'm sure you deserv'd a great Deal.

sp.speaker: L. Landsworth.
sp.p: Even Three Thousand Pounds a Year, besides Mony, Plate, and Jewels. This Mrs. Rich's Husband was my old Man's Banker, and once I saw her in the Country, besides she had money of mine in her hands, so to her, and this dear Town I came; resolving to perticipate all the innocent Liberty my Youth, my Wealth, and Sex desires.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Ah, Madam! had our Sex but your forbearance, they might all be happy.

sp.speaker: L. Landsworth.
sp.p: I am of the mind that Fortune offers every mortal their share of satisfaction; but if they pluck the green Fruit, forestal her purpose, or miss the ripen'd moment, they rarely have another prospect.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Right, Madam, and is it not the same in Love? If a Lady refuses the Man she likes, all her Adventures in that kind prove aukward and unlucky after it.

sp.speaker: L. Landsworth.
sp.p: Say'st thou so, Mrs. Betty; well I am resolv'd to indulge my Inclinations, and rather than not obtain the person I like, invert the Order of nature, and persue, tho' he flies.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Impossible, one glance of yours subdues the proudest Love-defier of them all.

sp.speaker: L. Landsworth.
sp.p: Pho, you flatter; but seriously my dear Confidant, being once condemn'd to Matrimony without ever asking my consent, now I have the freedom to make my own choice, and the whole World the Mart. ... I have the oddest Whimsies.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Then your Ladyship intends to venture on a second Marriage?

sp.speaker: L. Landsworth.
sp.p: Truly, Mrs. Betty, I believe so, why should we dissemble when we are alone?— but such a Husband I would have.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: What sort of a Husband? let's hear the Marks? that I may try to find the Man.

sp.speaker: L. Landsworth.
sp.p: He should be Gentile, yet not a Beau; Witty, yet no Debauche; susceptible of Love, yet abhorring lew'd Women; Learned, Poetical, Musical without one Dram of Vanity; in fine, very meritorious, yet very modest; generous to the last degree, and Master of no Estate; mightily in Love with me, and not so much as know I am worth the Cloaths I wear.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, to your Romances again Lady fair, 'tis only there you can converse with those Heros, this Town affords no such, I can assure you: Modest, Meritorious, and Genteel, ha, ha, ha, your Pardon, Madam, why such a Wight would not get his daily Bread, not Rags to cover his Nakedness; tis Frontless Impudence makes the Grand appearance, and carries the World before it.

sp.speaker: L. Landsworth.
sp.p: I suppose I shall increase your Laughter, when I tell you I fancy I have found the Man.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Landsworth.
sp.p: You know, throughly tir'd with the Impertinence within, and not being fitted to give or receive Visits, I have often rambled with my Woman Incognito— and have done the strangest things.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: What, for Heavens sake?

sp.speaker: L. Landsworth.
sp.p: Even lost my Heart; in Love, Mrs. Betty, desperately in Love.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: With whom, Dear Madam?

sp.speaker: L. Landsworth.
sp.p: Oh, a pretty Gentleman, who has all those accomplishments I desire writ in his Face, as plain as—

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: The Nose in't, I warrant.

sp.speaker: L. Landsworth.
sp.p: Yes truly, for all your jesting: I sate by him in the Play-House, and discover'd his Sense as taking as his Figure.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: But where was his modesty, when he attack'd a Mask?

sp.speaker: L. Landsworth.
sp.p: That's your mistake, 'twas I gave the onset, nay, went farther, appointed him a meeting there again, injoyn'd him not to dog me, nor endeavour to learn who I was, which he punctually obey'd.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: And you perform'd your Assignation.

sp.speaker: L. Landsworth.
sp.p: Yes indeed, last Night; and to try his Generosity, when the Door-keeper came into the side Box for Money, I seem'd in a great fright, and said, I had left my purse at home, he immediately offer'd me a Guinea, which tho' I accepted, by the melancholy Air of his Face, I guess'd it had not a Twin Brother.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Bless me, Madam! that pretence, and taking his mony, made you look like a Woman of the Town.

sp.speaker: L. Landsworth.
sp.p: So I design'd: I forc'd him to tell me his Name and Lodging, e'r I'de accept the favour, and now I have a Game to play, wherein you must assist me.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: In what ever you desire. Oh! Madam, Sir John Roverhead is just upon us.

sp.speaker: L. Landsworth.
sp.p: What luck is this! is there no avoiding the Fop?

div.stage: Enter Sir John Roverhead, and Chris. his Man.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ha, Chris.! the beautiful wealthy Widow of the North.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Why, Sir, she is not Mrs. Rich.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Sagely discover'd, but she's better, Mr. Wisdom, more desirable, and deeper in my Affections.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Your Pardon, Sir, I have done.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Stand back▪

sp.speaker: L. Landsworth.
sp.p: What postures the thing uses, to make it more ridiculous than nature first design'd it.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Now to be florid. [To Chris.] Sure some auspicious Planet rul'd to day, for every Star is witness, how often, when I have made my Visit here, I have sigh'd to see your Ladyship,—

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: Still taking Coach, or Chair. Have I not helpt you out, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir. John.
sp.p: Lord, Madam, such beauty, Wit and Dress what Man can bear?

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: Such affectation, folly and nonsense, what Woman can indure?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ay hey, Mrs.— Betty, what's the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: The effect of her Country ignorance.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: It must be so, for I think Chris, I am nicely Dress'd to day.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Ay, but perhaps she likes the Inward-man.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: She's a fool, that's certain. But, Mrs. Betty, I hope my Affairs stand well with your Lady; this was but a trifle whom I address'd too with my universal Gallantry, which had she receiv'd, I should have laugh'd at; my Valet knows 'tis my way to all that make an appearance.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Under Fifty.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Or above, if they make an appearance.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Ay, Sir John, 'tis you alone have the bewitching way, Court all the World, and catch my unweary Mistress by the by; because 'tis like Quality. Sir John. Like! that's degrading; I'de be an original, like nothing.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Nothing sure can be like you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: A witty Baggage this, we must ingage her.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Withal my heart, secure you the Mistress, and let me alone for the Maid. Sir John. Well, but Mrs. Betty, after this idle chat shall we crave leave to see your Mistriss.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: You may, and you only; she's at Cards.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I protest thou art charmingly dress'd, and pretty, I vow; what Design have you to day?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Is it to me you speak, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: To whom else?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I thought, like a Poet you were repeating, and design'd the Complement for the next of Quality you met.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Fie, fie, let me dye if you are not the prettiest, amiable Creature I know: Prythee who makes thy Mantoe's; how modestly the little Creature dresses her Head too!

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, this is excess of French breeding: But, Sir John, you forget my Lady expects you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I shall ever forget her when I look upon thee, my Life, my Soul, She threw by her Knotting in haste— [Sings.] ho, ho, ho, come along Chris. I've shot her flying. And caught me about my well shap'd wast— [Sings.] ho, ho, ho,

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: So, this is the high top Fool in my Lady's equipage, the favour'd Fool, and she has enough in her Train to give a Man of sense the spleen but to hear her Catalogue. Well, since Fortune has thrown me into this Chamber-maid Station, I'le revenge her Cruelty, and plague her Favourites.
sp.l: No 〈◊〉 by me shall e'er successful prove,
My Plots shall help the Man of Sense in Love.

div.head: ACT II.

sp.speaker: Belvoir.
sp.p: HOw now Jack, is thy Master within?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Belvoir.
sp.p: No, Sir; Let me come Morning, Noon, or Night, still I am answer'd, No, Sir; 'twas by accident I found his Lodgings, and I plainly perceive he is deny'd; this is most injurious to our former Friendship, quite contrary to the Contract made when we were fellow Students, when I was only Clerimonts, and Clerimont Belvoirs.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, my Master's strangely alter'd; but I dare not tell.

sp.speaker: Belvoir.
sp.p: Come, for once I'le tempt thee to a breach of Trust, I may do him service; I hear his Father's dead.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Ah, Sir! that's his grief, the very fountain of his Discontment.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Trust me Jack, few Young Gentlemen use to break their Hearts for such a Loss.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Yes, if they are Younger Brothers, and left not worth a Groat; 'twill go a great way with them, a great way indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But he was the Old Lord's Favourit, who had Land enough without entail to make my Clermont happy.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Alas! Mr. Bellvoir, I find you know not our Story.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Not the particulars, only what I've heard from fame; if thou believest me thy Masters Friend, hide nothing from me.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: I do, so notwithstanding his Commands, you shall hear our misfortunes. You know my Master's Elder Brother, is a perfect Squire, on my Conscience the product of two Virginities, such an unaccountable Blockhead, that tho' he gave the assured proof of spending his Fathers Estate, and did it so ungenteely, that he was despis'd by Men of Sense, shun'd by all but the unthinking Rabble, Rediculous even below Lampooning.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why Jack, the Town improves thee beyond the University, thou grow'st Witty.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: No, 'tis the Approach of Poverty whets my Spleen; I gad if I am reduc'd to Rags I'll spare ne'r an Elder Brother of them all, tho' he were a Prince.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A well a day, for the poor Gentlemen in gilt Coaches. But proceed to the matter, good Friend John.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Why this Dunce, I think I call'd him before, shatter Brains.—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hold.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Whose sole delight lay in his Kindred Hounds, who for his Hunting Companions, entertain'd all the Lubbers of the four adjacent Parishes, till the Country was going to Petition the Parliament for Labourers; this Monster of the Woods, this—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well what of him.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Has got every Penny of my Old Lord's Estate, whilst my Master, the most deserving of his Race, (tho' I say it that should not) is left to Starve, Rob, Drown, or what he pleases.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But how came this to pass, Jack, ha?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Why that damn'd jilt Fortune, or her left-handed Daughter, as blind as she, Chance.

sp.speaker: Belvoir.
sp.p: A mischance upon my word.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: A confounded one. My old Lord lay long Bed-rid of the Gout, and the Wight I have describ'd, liv'd in an Estate some few Miles distant, one day Hunting that way, he bethought himself, and made his sick Father a Visit; but knowing he could not sit a moment without talking to his beloved Jowler, Ringwood, &c. takes the whole Kennel along with him into the Chamber, whilst the t'other Kennel below (I mean the Peasants) were so sharp set, they scarce left my Lord an unmaul'd Dish to come to his Table.

sp.speaker: Bellvour.
sp.p: Horrid, filthy Brutes!

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: In fine, this so exasperated the old Man that in a rage he burnt his Will, designing to leave my Master whatever was in his power; but the malicious Fates decreed it otherwise, for that very night the anger'd Father dy'd suddenly, and all his Wealth fell to that soft-headed Fool in one Swoop; and the De'il, I say, do him good with it.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Pho, there must be application made to him, Jack, this must not be suffer'd.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: To his Huntsman apply then, for he's his only Oracle.

sp.speaker: Belvoir.
sp.p: Their's Mrs. Clerimont in Town his first Cousin, a vast fortune, and one who has a larger share of Wit and Goodness; she shall be consulted. What, a young Gentleman shall never droop for missing a paltry Fortune.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Dear Sir, do your best. But now I beg of you to be gone; I hear him coming, and he will be in such a Passion if he discover I have been talking to you, or told he was at home; for 'tis his humour to hide from all his Friends.

sp.speaker: Belv.
sp.p: Well, I'le not cross him now, but certainly find out some way to assist him. Farewel. honest Jack, be sure you prove faithful and kind to him.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Upon my veracity to my uttermost. I only wish to serve him—
sp.stage: Exit Belvoir. [Jack stands out of sight

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Mine's not the Mourning of an Heir; Oh! my Noble Father sure I should have griev'd enough for thee, for thy unspeakable loss, without additional Calamities: What will become of me; must I wait at proud Men's doors, and cring for an admittance? Can I flatter the puft up Lord, and fawn for a vile Office? Debase my immortal Soul to feed this moulding Clay? 'Tis impossible, 'tis more than Man can bear!

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: sir.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: What.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: I thought you call'd.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Thou art too officions; I have advis'd thee oft to leave me, and seek thy fortune where the Goddess smiles, I am a Wretch that now is sinking lower than his own dispairing Thoughts can frame.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, is this all the Philosophy you have learn'd, think I am the best proficient, starving frights not me half so much as parting; faith, tho' the World is crowded with knaves that an honest Gentleman can scarce breath, I'le jostle stoutly but you shall have Elbow room.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Poor Fellow! thou differest from the common Tribe of Servants; they fly Poverty worse than Infection; or else with sawcy Impuence insult.

div.stage: Enter a Coachman with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Coachman.
sp.p: Is this Mr. Clerimont's Lodging?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Well, and what then, how came you here without calling me? What's your Name, and what's your Business?

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Not with you, Sawce-box.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: How, Sirrah!

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Peace; my Name is Clerimont▪

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Then, Sir, there's a Lady in my Coach has sent you this, she says it requires no Answer.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Ha, Gold! fly Jack, call him back.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: [Pulling in the Coachman.] Heark-yee, you Sneak-nose, Hounds-face, you have Affronted my Master.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Why, fool, I brought him Money.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: I thought so, ye Pimp, he scorns it.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Here, return this back; tell the Lady she mistakes the Man, and I'll wait upon her where she appoints, and convince her that she does.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Gad, a notable Mistake.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Rascal, no fingering. Follow you, and take the Number of his Coach; if you are not honest, Sirrah, I shall find a time to cut your Ears off.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: I'll watch him, I warrant. Bring Money to my Master! Sirrah, get you gone.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Sure they are all distracted!

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: From my Mask in the Play-house: By my Life a very Harlot: How few in my Circumstances wou'd refuse these offers; but my Nature's quite otherwise, I cannot be oblig'd where I contemn, nor live so vile a way: Not but the temptation's doubly baited, Profit and Pleasure; for tho' the Baggage is loose as the wanton Winds, yet she is Witty beyond her Sex: What a medley's here.

When I tell ye I am in Love, by that modest Air, and down cast Look of yours, I guess you'l think me mad, and expect (according to the Damsels in Romance) I should
have a Fit of Sickness, been at the Point of death, e'er made the discovery: But Women of my Character are not so nice. I am a Mistress, have abundance of Money, if you have but little, a wise Man may pick comfort out of this. I send you a Token, as an earnest of my future favours; agreeable to your wonted Obedience come not to the Coach, but meet me at Four in the Park, and thank me with your Acceptance. Ha, ha, ha, ha, I see the Devil's not wanting on his part, he'de have me a greater Sinner e'er I come to despair. The Postscript is the same mad stuff.
sp.l: You shall know me by an affected motion in my
Walk, and a Bell toss with my head, humph!

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: The Lady's gone, Sir, and the Money too: Gad, Sir, tho' to please you, I was in a passion, yet my mouth water'd plaguily at the Gold.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: What said the Creature?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: The Creature! Gad she was an Angel. She pull'd off her Mask, I believe, to laugh freely, for she burst out vehemently; and when the Man said you'd have none on't, she gave her self a swing, and cry'd, the more fool he, drive on Coachman.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: So merry! but 'tis her time whilst Youth and Beauty lasts; she'll have Years enough of Sorrow.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Sir, my Landlady's a coming, you have us'd her so to sack and Chocolate in a morning, that she'l ne'er fail you.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Pish, I am sick of her Impertinence.
Good morrow Mr. Clerimont; good Lord, still walking with that melancholy air! Well, well, were I such a pretty Gentleman, I'de defy Fortune.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Prithee, Landlady, what would you have me do; if you think the Ladies will like me so well, take my Picture and hang it out at your Belcony; e'en make your best of me, if that will content ye.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fidget.
sp.p: Fy, fy, you might have private Chamber-practice enough, if you'd give your mind to't: Us'd my life, if the young handsome Fellows were like you, there wou'd never have come so many of them to their Coach and Six. Let me tell ye, Mr. Clerimont, if I thought you had been of this reserv'd Humour, I'de not have let my Lodgings to you. I us'd to have Women of Quality to my fine Gentlemen, and Suppers dress'd in my House have lasted my Famy a Week; besides that put into my hand that shall be nameless, else I had ne'er liv'd in the Credit you see me in these Twenty Years in the Parish.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Good Mrs. Fidget.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fidget.
sp.p: [Nay you shall hear me.] Brought up my Daughters as I have done: As fine Women, tho' I say it, as any that adorn Covent Garden Church.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Church! I should rather have thought they'd adorn the Play-house.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fidget.
sp.p: Now out uponyou, Mr. Clerimont, my Daughters are never seen at the Play-house; I bring them up in the fear of Heaven.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Yes, and they are both Married in the fear of Heaven too: For neither of them troubled the Church in that Affair, as I have been told.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fidget.
sp.p: Well, Saucy-face. But, Mr. Clerimont, what I have said is all for your good, and I hope you do take it into your Consideration: For truly to day there came a very pretty Lady, and notwithstanding your Order, I sent up the Coachman: I am willing to bring you to Preferment.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Bring me to the Pox, and the Devil—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fidget.
sp.p: Marry gap, is this my Thanks!

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: I tell ye, I am tir'd of these morning Lectures, and if my Lodgings cannot be free from noise and impertinence, I must quit them. Follow me, Jack, I'll take the air.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fidget.
sp.p: So out of sorts, and gone without giving me my Mornings-Draught: Why, Master John, Master John, give me the Key of the Closset, I must rummage it for a Dram of the Bottle: Udsflesh I shan't be in humour again this half hour, the Man's a fool, I think.
sp.l: When Beauty courts the charming Pleasures shun,
Be vertuous, tho' he's sure to be undone;
He's mad, Udsflesh! I'd sooner turn a Nun.

div.stage: Scene draws and discovers Mrs. Rich, Mrs. Trickwell, and Lady la Basset, Rising from Play.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trickwell
sp.p: to Mrs. Rich. I protest your Ladyship plays to a miracle; but I wou'd not have had you ventur'd Money yet.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Oh pardon me, Madam, I should not have minded it else. But do you think I shall ever be capable?

sp.speaker: La Basset.
sp.p: Why, you are perfect already; a wonderful apprehension.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Oh, fie! My Lady la Basset, you compliment in reality; may I hope to play at Court? I have a great ambition to play at Court: Oh my Stars! I shou'd torment our City Ladies to death, to talk of Honours done me at Court.

sp.speaker: La Basset.
sp.p: Yes, yes, you shall be introduc'd, and honour'd at Court, I'll promise ye, or my Interest fails me; and for setting it out let me alone, I'll make their Ears tingle, I faith.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Oh, my dear, dear Lady Basset, let me imbrace ye, the very conception on't is felicity to the highest degree. Mon Dieu! How we'll teaze the little Citty Creatures.
Madam, Sir John Roverhead is come to wait on you, and has got some Musick to entertain your Ladyships.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Oh Heavens! That Master of Accomplishments! Instruct me, dear Ladies, how to receive him.

sp.speaker: Lady Basset.
sp.p: Seem in a Cabal, then burst out a laughing, and let fall some misterious Words that tend towards Scandal.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Good! ridiculous to the highest degree, that ever a Woman of her Quality shou'd make such a faux pas, the Town will ring on't: Oh, my Stars! 'Tis something so odd, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trickwell.
sp.p: Transportingly foolish! Yet it makes me laugh, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: La Basset.
sp.p: Who can forbear, ha, ha, ha.
Pardon, Ladies, the interruption; may I participate; I dye to laugh in consort with Women of your Wit and Merit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Oh fie! Sir John, 'tis a secret upon my word; we must be tender of our own Sex; you are but too well acquainted with our weakness; Scandal of an hour old is as much out of date with you, as a Gazette in the Afternoon to the Sots that hunt forreign News.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p:
News! gad Madam, there's no such thing, there's nothing new under
the Sun; the World is a continual round of nauseous repetition; in the last Generation, and this, young Girls were mad for Husbands, then mad to get rid of 'em; Sharpers, had their Cullies; Gamesters, their Fools; Physicians kill'd their Patients, and were paid for't; Lawyers got Estates, and their Clients were undone with Suing for 'em; Courtiers Promises, and Bullies Oaths, ever made a great Noise, and signify'd nothing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Satyrical, I vow! Why, you are in a mortifying way, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Indeed scarce sit to appear before your Ladyship: I have had a Billet-doux from a Woman of Sixty, which has given me the Spleen to that degree, I could our-rail a Hypocritical Fanatick.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Sixty! Pleasant, I protest.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: She's a walking Memento mori; I have suffer'd some time under the persecution, and in bitterness and Gall, instead of Ink, have wrote a Stanza, to shew how awkardly an old Woman makes advances.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Oh, dear Sir John, let us have it.

sp.speaker: La Basset.
sp.p: We are all Petitioners.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: You shall Command me, Ladies.

lg.l: DElia tir'd Strephon with her Flame,
While languishing she view'd him,
The well dress'd Youth despis'd the Dame
But still old Puss pursu'd him.
Some pitty on a Wretch bestow,
That lies at your Devotion:
Perhaps near Fifty Years ago,
Some might have lik'd the Motion.
No Heart like mine did ever burn,
I'm rich too, I'le assure you;
And I must tell you in return,
You're uglier than a Fury.
If you, proud Youth, my Flame despise,
I'le hang me in my Garters:
Why, then make hast to win the Prize,
Among Love's foolish Martyrs.
Can you see Delia brought so low,
And make her no Requitals?
Delia may to the Devil go
For Strephon, stop my Vitals.
I'le be as Constant as a Dove,
And always we'l be Billing:
No more damn'd Stories of your Love,
Your very Breath is killing.
These Eyes for you shall learn to shine,
That twinkle in their Sockets.
I'le never in a Cellar dine,
When I may go to Lockets.
What in my Charms and Youth I want,
I'le make it up in Duty.
Prithee leave off this foolish Cant,
I'le stoop to nought but Beauty.

div.stage: After the Song Mrs. Trickwell to Mrs. Rich, aside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trickwell.
sp.p: Did you observe how my Lady la Bassett Ey'd Sir John?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Yes, and am pleas'd with it: I would not have a Fellow pretend to me, that all the Fine Women in Town are not fond of. Our Thanks in abundance, 'tis wonderful pretty.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Your Pardon, harsh, and untunable, like the Subject.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Betty. Betty speaking to Mrs. Rich aside.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich
sp.p: will not be answer'd, Madam, I had much ado to keep him out here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Ladies, let me beg you would take Sir John into the Drawing-Room, and entertain him a moment. A hideous Citizen will tease me about a little Business, but I'll dispatch him in the third part of a Minute, and rejoyn the Agreeable Conversation.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: We shall wait with Impatience, Madam.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Rich, meeting Mrs. Rich and Betty.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: There he walks, Madam, he would stay in spight of me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Ah, Mr. Rich! What design brings you hither? Your Absence this Day would have been very obliging; but since you are here, let's finish pray as soon as you can. Well, what's the Business?

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Hey-day! What's this? Good Madam Rich, my Sister-in-Law, how despisingly you talk? Hark ye, hark ye, this Behaviour does not become ye; and without telling you what relates to me, you'll one Day repent of your ridiculous way of living, and carriage.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: An Elbow-Chair, Betty, I foresee Mr. Rich intends to Talk me to Sleep.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: No, Madam, on the contrary; for were you in your right Senses, what I have to say would most terribly keep you Awake.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: You strangely concern your self with my Conduct.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: And who will concern himself, if I dont? You are my Daughters Aunt, Widow of Paul Rich my Brother, and I will not have it said upon the Exchange, That my Brother's Widow, and Daughters Aunt, is run stark Mad.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: How Mad! You lose all Respect, Mr. Rich; but I shall find a way to get rid of you, that I may hear no more such Sottish Unmannerly Language, to which I scorn to answer.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Oh! 'Slife, Madam Rich, you ought to get rid of all your Ridiculous Airs of Quality and Greatness, that you may receive no more Affronts equal to this Days.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: You ought not, Mr. Rich, to reproach me of that, where I am only expos'd, because I'm thought your Sister-in-Law; but there's an end of that, Mr. Rich, I'll have it publish'd in the Gazette, That since my Widowhood, I am no more your Sister, and so I renounce you for my Brother-in-Law, Mr. Rich; and since hitherto my Expences, my Noble manner of living, and what I every Day practice, could never correct the fault of having once been a Citizen's Wife. I do now pretend—

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Zooks, Madam Rich, 'tis the best part of your History, that Name of Rich; and had it not been for the good Conduct of the poor Deceas'd, you had not been in a Condition for so much Pomp and Greatness. I wou'd fain know—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Courage, Courage, Mr. Rich, you do well, talk on, talk on, 'tis your last time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p:
I wou'd fain know, let me tell you, if it would not be more decent for you to have a good grave Coach, lin'd with an Olive-colour'd Cloth, a Lean Coachman in a Dark-brown Coat, a little Modest Boy with short Hair to open the Door, and a pair of gentle Geldings, than all this sumptuous Equipage, that makes People inquire who you are; these modish prauncing Flanders, that dash the Industrious People that walk; and all that useless Numerous Train, which
makes you despis'd by the People of Quality, envied by your Equals, and curs'd by the Mob: You ought, Mrs. Rich, to retrench all this Greatness and Folly with which you are surrounded.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: But, Sir— What's the matter with you, Madam?

div.stage: [To Mrs. Rich, who Coughs and Spits.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: I take Breath, Betty, Is not Mr. Rich come to his second Point?

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: No, good Mrs. Rich, and I return still to the Equipage.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Oh, the long-winded tiresome Man!

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Among the rest, what d'ye do with that huge Bulky Coachman, with his Curling Whiskers like a Dutch Mastiff's Tail? 'Zbud he looks as if he belong'd to the Czar of Muscovy.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: But, Sir, wou'd you have my Lady turn Barber, and shave her Coachman?

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: No, but she may turn him away, and take another.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Well, Sir, one Word's as good as a thousand, I pretend to live as I please, and will have none of your Council; I laugh at you and all your Reproofs; I am a widow, and depend on no Body but my self. You come here and controul me, as if you had an absolute Authority over me. Oh, my Stars! What rudeness are you guilty of? But it is your City breeding.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Still abusing the City, 'tis a shame, Mrs. Rich, a burning shame. I tell thee, thou proud vain thing, thou gilt Ginger-Bread; the City is famous for Men substantial in their Persons, their Purses, their Credits, when your Limberham'd, this end of the Town Beaux, are the half product of Nature, wretchedly piec'd up by Art, weak in their Bodies, their Brains, their every thing; and Udsbones! They have no more Credit, than they have Religion; whilst as I said before the City is famous for—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Cuckolds: Good Mr. Rich take my Advice, and take breath; you have outdone one of our Holders-forth, upon my word ye have.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: [Mimiking her.] Upon my word ye have; What an Affected Tone's there? Gadzooks my Brother Rich was a Fool.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: That's no wonder; most Citizens are.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Yes, to their Wives, ungrateful Cockatrice; and he Blind— Credulous Man, to pretend to leave my Daughter a Fortune to your Management, forsooth: Gadzooks, I had rather he had left her never a Groat.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: So had I; there we agree once, put it down, Betty, for a Miracle. Oh! Is it done? Have ye said all? Will you go out of my House, or must I go? Upon my word I have Company waits for me, that are a thousand and a thousand times more ingaging; Will ye believe me, or no, Mr. Rich?

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: What Company? Fools, I warrant 'em.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: He must be convinc'd: Perhaps, Betty, that will drive him hence, open the Door.

div.stage: Scene draws and discovers Sir John, Lady Bassett, Mrs. Trickwell, and Vermin a Footman.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich continues.
sp.p:
Oh! I am just suffocated with Impertinence, expiring under the heavy load of Nonsense: Dear Lady Basset revenge me, redicule that lump of the City till he Frets himself into shape; I'll introduce ye: Look ye, Sir, this is
the Honourable Lady Basset, this is the Ingenious Mrs. Trickwell; the Gentleman I leave to speak for himself.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I am, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich
sp.p: (roughly.) And what are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Why, your humble Servant, Sir, that's all, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lady Bassett.
sp.p: I vow he nods like the Statue in Don John, ha, ha, he he.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trickwell.
sp.p: And looks like—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: A Citizen, and that's rediculous enough of all Conscience, he, he.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: (Mimiking.) Good lack, he, he, he: Gadzooks you are a parcel of Tawdry Insignificant Butterflies; if ye provoke me, I'll draw your Pictures with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Dawley has done mine at length already, much more to my satisfaction; it hangs as Court in a Dutchesses Bed-chamber, Citt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: The Devil it does? the Mop that cleans it set upright, and good Drapery, would be a better Figure.

sp.speaker: Lady Bassett.
sp.p: Filthy Simile.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trickwell.
sp.p: Why, m' Amie, this is the Reverse of Sir Courtly; a second Surly, I protest.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Thou wretched Woman, whom I justly shame to call Sister, these are things that live on thee, prey on thy very substance, and have no more Worth, or real Quality than the Ornament of Pageants: Look, here's the Equipage of one, those lank Cheeks are to be fill'd out at thy Table; (pulls Vermin forward) and thy Pocket look'd at Games thou dost not understand, for Rigging.

sp.speaker: Lady Bassett.
sp.p: Now out upon ye; stand back Vermin; see if the ill-natur'd Man has not quite dash'd the Boy? 'Tis the filthy Taylor's fault.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: What, he'll Trust no longer.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Fie, Mr. Rich, this is prodigiously abusive, upon my Honour; I presume you've never been at the Court.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Nor you at the Camp, which now's the only way to make a perfect Courtier: I tell thee, Fop, if thou art known there, 'tis only for thy Folly; thy Reputation lies in ruining others, which thou dost infallibly, by being once in their Company; and thy chiefest accomplishment is taking Snuff with a Bel Air, Patching, Painting, Powdering like a Woman, and squeaking like an Eunuch, Gadzooks.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Look ye, if you are offended, or think the Ladies so, as much a Citizen as I am, I wear a Sword, and follow me ye Caper-cutter if ye dare.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Some Colonel of the Train-bands, I warrant; I'll not disorder my Dress. I am weary of this fulsome stuff; to the Park my Angels, and let's breath a little.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ay, ay, to the Park, to the Park.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Withal my heart to the Park: Lacquies, is my Coach there? But my House is at your Service: Cool your self sweet Sir John, whilst we laugh at this Adventure; shall we not Lady Bassett?

sp.speaker: L. Bassett.
sp.p: I cannot help it.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Nor I upon my Honour.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Why what the Devil's here to do, Betty?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: My Mistress is run stark staring Mad, but I humour her Distraction till we can find a way to cure it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Prithee let's in and consult; I plac'd thee here for that purpose, and trust in thee.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I will ever prove faithful, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.l: Two powerful Fiends, Lust and Ambition reign
In this Rich, Buxom Widows sickly Brain;
To lay them both, a Husband must be had,
Beauxish and Young, with sounding Titles clad;
But that shall be your Care and mine, ' ygad.

div.head: ACT III.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clerim.
sp.p: THis is strange News you tell me of my Cousin; I heard indeed the Unhappy Accident of his Father's Sudden Death, but thought he had been still in the Country.

sp.speaker: Belvoir.
sp.p: No, he lives in Town retired, shuns all his Acquaintance; his Noble Mind surmounts his Fortunes, and he disdains to be obliged; it affects me strongly, for I loved him with such a Passion; loved him, that I thought till I beheld your Beauteous self, it could never have been exceeded.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clerimont.
sp.p: When I reflect how cold our present Friendships are, I needs must own 'tis nobly Generous in you to seek and serve him in this Distress; nor shall my Assistance any way be wanting, let us but find the means.

sp.speaker: Belvoir.
sp.p: First we must indeavour to see him, reconcile him to the World, and try to cure his Melancholy.

sp.speaker: Lucinda.
sp.p: Madam, there's a Gentleman below who says his Name is Clerimont.

sp.speaker: Belvoir.
sp.p: Clerimont!

sp.speaker: Lucinda.
sp.p: He seems of some far Country by his Dress and Attendance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Clerimont.
sp.p: On my Life the Elder Brother: This may prove lucky, bring him up: Come, Sir, we will have some contrivance how to make the Younger easie.

sp.speaker: Belvoir.
sp.p: Such Goodness and Ingenuity as yours cannot fail, when 'tis employ'd for Merit.

div.stage: Enter the Elder Clerimont and Lucetta, followed by Toby leading two Hounds coupled.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: [Speaks entring.] Nay, Sweet-heart, dant fear your Rooms, my Dogs have been in Ladies Chambers afore now, my Lady Mother wou'd let 'em lie on her Bed rather than cross me: Love me, love my Dog, as the Saying is▪ Come along Toby.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: What a Scene is here!

sp.speaker: Belvoie.
sp.p: Exactly as Jack describ'd him.

sp.speaker: Servant Couz:
sp.p: Do yee see I am come to Lounnon: he 'tis no matter for Ceremony; I ha just now been bussing Jewel, might-hap you dant care to be kiss'd after the Dog.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: You are in the right on't, 'tis not material.

sp.speaker: Elder Cler.
sp.p: I have a free way, Couz, you must excuse me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Cler.
sp.p: Oh, you are very welcome.

sp.speaker: Elder Cler.
sp.p: No for matter o'that I shant trouble you, I shall lie in my Inn. Here's Toby, my Huntsman, he'd a main mind to see Lounnon, so I did it to please the Booby; ha Toby.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Ne, ne Master, dant; lay it awl upon me; an any bad chance shou'd happen, you were as forward as I, else we'd ne'r a come; you are a little too stubborn, by the Mess.

sp.speaker: Belvoir.
sp.p: Well said Toby; Toby has a free way too, I perceive, Sir.

sp.speaker: Elder Cler.
sp.p: Yes marry I allow it him: He is a rare Huntsman. Shew thy parts Toby, hallow, hallow, Toby.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Holla, holla, holla, &c.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Oh! 'tis mighty well. But, good Cousin, it goes quite thro' my head.

sp.speaker: Elder Cler.
sp.p: Might hap so, you are used not to it. Ha boys! He'll make the Woods ring y-faith.

sp.speaker: Belvoir.
sp.p: 'Tis much better there, I believe.

sp.speaker: Elder Cler.
sp.p: Good Lord! it offends your tender Ears, does it? I warrant you are one of the Zilken Sparks a rough-Wind wou'd blow to pieces. Pardon me Couz, I must be merry.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: O! the Gentleman will take nothing ill from a Relation of mine.

sp.speaker: Elder Cler.
sp.p: Midhap he is your Husband, or midhap he is your Sweet-heart, for he creeps main close to yee.

sp.speaker: Belvoir.
sp.p: I am the humblest of the Lady's Servants.

sp.speaker: Elder Cler.
sp.p: Oh ho! her humble Servant, that's all one; in our Country they call 'um Sweet-hearts, or Suitors; 'tis e'n all one.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Pray Cousin, give me leave to ask you if you are married yet, or not.

sp.speaker: Elder Cler.
sp.p: No, by my tackings, I ha e'n more Wit than that comes to; I learn'd so much by my Dogs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: By your Dogs?

sp.speaker: Elder Cler.
sp.p: Aye, by my Dogs: See this Couple now how they lear, how spitefully they look at one another. I tell thee Couz, this is Jewel, and this is Beauty; the Bitch is Beauty, do yee mark me; Couz▪ there was not two Dogs in the whole Pack lov'd like these two, they play'd together like two Kittens; nay, for all they are Hounds, one wou'd not eat without t'other, and now they are join'd their hate is the same; one snarls, t'other bites, one pulls this way, t'other that; Gadzooks! they'd either venture hanging to be parted; therefore no coupling for me, I say, ha, ha, ha, ha, Couz.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Nay, by the Mess this is true, Master has spoken all at once; Master's a shrowd Man, foth and troth.

sp.speaker: Elder Cler.
sp.p: Well, but Couz, I come to Lounon a purpose to see Sports we han't i' th' Country, and to spend my money, de yee see.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: What Diversions are you for?

sp.speaker: Elder Cler.
sp.p: Why look yee, I'de vain see a good Bear-baiting, and I'de see the Tigre, Ah! that's a parlous Beast; we will see the Tigre, shan't we Toby?

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Aye Udslid, tho' I shall be a little avraid.

sp.speaker: Belvoir.
sp.p: You wou'd not have the Lady carry you to those Places, I hope?

sp.speaker: Elder Cler.
sp.p: Aye, why not, Sir? They'l see I'me a Country Man, and that wan't disgrace her, besides I have Four thousand pounds a Year, for all I wear my own hair, Monsieur Perriwig.

sp.speaker: Belvoir.
sp.p: The more's the pitty.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Peace, Mr. Belvoir, we shall lose our design else. Cousin, 'tis impossible for me to go to the Bear-Garden; if you'l oblige me, you shall spend this day with me, and participate of the pleasures I take, to morrow some fitter Companion shall shew you what you like better.

sp.speaker: Elder Cler.
sp.p: A match! I dan't pass upon't, if I do throw away a day with you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: We'l first to the Park; and then in the Afternoon to the Play.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Ay, d'ye ', Master, do ye; Udslid, I ha long'd to zee a Play, e'er since I zaw the Poppet-shew at our Vare.

sp.speaker: Elder Cler.
sp.p: Come, my poor Dogs! Evads, Coz. you'l scarce think it, Ide as lieve kiss this poor Creature, as e'er a Lady in Christendom— I'm sure her Breath's as sweet; they'l not like London; we must hasten down again, Toby.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Ay, Master; when we've zeen a little; here's rare vine Voke!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Lead, Mr. Belvoir.

sp.speaker: Belvoir.
sp.p: We shall be the Sport of the Park.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: No matter; my Cousin shall Gallant me.

sp.speaker: Elder Cler.
sp.p: Come on, i'faith! Follow, Toby!

div.stage: Enter Lady Landsworth and Mrs. Betty.

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: He refus'd it, my best Confidante! Nobly despis'd the shining Gold! By all my amorous Stars, he has bravely won my Heart! Panting and warm I feel him there! Oh! the dear God of my desire.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: In Raptures, nay, then you are lost indeed! Ha! here comes my Lady, and her worthy Train!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: My Lady Landsworth! Let us only make our Honours en passent— Mon Dieu! I did not think't had been in her— I protest to a Miracle!

div.stage: [Mrs. Rich Courtsey's to L. Landsworth, with ridiculous Airs. L. Landsworth mimicks her.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Shall we not Address?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: No, no, no, no. Away to the Mall.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ah me!

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: There's a Foil to my Hero! What a languishing Air the Fop put on! When such Stuff as that enters into my Thoughts, I shall turn Girl again, and play with Babies.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bett.
sp.p: See! Who walks there in Mourning!

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p:
Bless me! You made me start: 'Tis he! Yes; that's the shape, where manly Majesty's Triumphant! Who wou'd not be in love with Sorrow, when they see it in that Face: Who wou'd not long to remove the Cause; and dress
it up in charming Smiles: Forgive me, Virtue! Forgive, me Love, if I a little farther make the Trial— Now to disguise my Face and Heart—

div.stage: [Clasps on her Mask, and walks carelesly off.]

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Do ye think ye shall know her, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Know her! 'Tis impossible to mistake! Gay, as the gaudy Sun, or distant flowry Fields! She moves like Air, and throws her Charms around; But, be not caught my Soul! She is, what I wou'd still abhor— a Name, wou'd blacken her Lilly'd Bosom, and wither all the Roses that spread that face of Beauty!

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: But, Sir! If she has a World of Money, Sir,—

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Peace, Fool!

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: I ha' done, Sir! But abundance of Money covers a multitude of Faults— That's all, Sir!

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Blockhead!— Why so fast, fair Lady? At this rate, by that time a Man has over-taken ye, he'l have lost the Breath he shou'd imploy, in saying fine things— Will ye not stay?

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: Not stay! Yes, stay an Age; fixt never to remove: An everlasting Monument of Love. I know you doat upon Heroique: I have been Reading three whining Plays this morning, that I may Love in your strain.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: For Heaven's sake, tell me truly, what thou art; for, sure, there's something in thee I so love and hate, that, were my Fortune kind, I shall ne'er be happy more.

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: I'l tell ye, with a truth equal to the freedom I use; (for sincerity is all the Virtue I pretend to.) It was my first Fate to be kept by an Alderman, but he was formal, stiff, and too suspicious for my humor; so I fled from him into the Arms of a brisk, airy, young Collonel; then the Days were spent in Revels. When he went to Flanders, I Campaign'd it too; but, ah! as I had dress'd my fluttering Hero up, like any Bridegroom, a saucy Bullet came and spoil'd the work of Tailers, Milleners, and fifty Trades besides: Down dropt the Beau.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: You speak this without any Concern.

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: Alass! grieving for the Dead wou'd spoil us for the Living. Now, I'am a Perquisite of a Country Gentleman; a Man of Gravity, and one of the pious Senators; a great Stickler against Wenching and Prophaneness. He allows me Wealth enough, and Liberty enough. Besides him, I have two or three Interlopers, each fancying himself my Particular, when, for my part, I care nor a straw for any of 'em. But, ah! amongst my numerous Lovers, I know not how, Myrtillo has crept too near my Heart;— That's meaning you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: The Relation freezes up my Youthful Blood, and checks Desire with horror! Does none tell thee what a Wretch thou art?

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: None. They call me Goddess, Angel, and court me with unbated Fires; the first, the very earliest Product of the Year, Dainties sit for Queen's Tables, still load the Board; far fetch'd Wines, such as unbend the Soul from Cares, and lock up every Thought that wou'd disturb us;— yet amidst this flowing plenty; amidst this Crowd of Flatterers, my aukward Fancy sickens at their offer'd Loves; loaths their soft Indearments, and builds its sole happiness in manly roughness like Yours.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p:
Thou art one of Nature's Favourites; form'd when she was gay, and deckt in her own Smiles; yet me you cannot charm; there's a Rustick, out of
fashion-grace, a modest Innocence, which only takes my Soul; nor can I value Favors, that may be bought with any other Price than Love.

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: [Aside] He speaks, as my own Heart had Coin'd the Words: I wou'd not be too Credulous: Believe me, Sir, I am not us'd to Woo, or be Refus'd; but, I perceive when once we Love, we quit our Pride; I can bear Reproof from you; and rather than not see ye; see you still to chide me.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: No. I must fly, if I'de be safe; I cannot boast a Virtue Stoiceal enough, to behold you with Indifference; those Eyes were made to Conquer! Oh pity, that they scatter Contagion only! I could crawl low as the Earth to touch that beauteous hand; but when I reflect, a sensless Fop, for some vain Present, may riffle all those Sweets; then, I cou'd eat my Lips, e'er join 'em to Infection— Farewel.

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: Stay but some Moments longer; I have a few things more to offer; hear 'em; perhaps I ne'er may trouble you agen.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: I shall be Fool'd at last; believe her Love; trust her, and be undone!— What wou'd ye say?

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: Come this way, lest we are observ'd.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Is thy Lady so plaguy Rich, say'st thou Damsel?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Rich! Why she values a Hundred Pounds, no more than I do a Brass Farthing— She makes nothing to present a Man, she likes, with a Coach and Six— and your Master here, with his puling Modesty, will stand preaching Morals, till he has baulk'd her Fancy, and then 'twill be in vain to cry peccavi; for she, like Opportunity, when once she turns her back, leaves no grasping hold.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Hark ye, my Dear, can ye keep a Secret.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: As well as any of my Sex; according as the Nature of the Secret is; if 'twill make no mischief; take away no Body's Fame: In short, if 'twill do rather Good than Harm to divulge it; ten to one but it goes no farther for me.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Well, that's ingenious; and I'l trust thee. This Master of Mine is the veriest Libertine the whole Town affords; has tir'd Vice in every one of her shapes; and now, fortsooth, for variety, turns Hypocrite, that he may find their pleasures out.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Ha! is't possible?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: True, upon my honour; tho' he'd kill me shou'd he know I discover'd it; and deny all, with a Face as grave as a Phanatick— Oh! He's a rare Mimick.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: But, how shall my Lady be convinc'd he is such a Rake, if he'l deny't?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Our Landlady sells China, bring her thither; my Master will never know: She'l tell you as much— (Aside.) I can make my Landlady say what I will.— Well Jack— thy Brain shall still secure this Cargo.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: If she thinks it worth her while to inquire, I'l tell her— Look they are Parting.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Udso, so they are indeed— I must after; ply him, my Dear, and I'l ply thee.

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: Oh my dear Betty! how shall I express my Joys! Sure, such a Man no Age produced before! He's the Phaenix of his Kind!

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I wish he prove so.

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Hush! here comes Mrs. Clerimont, you have so often sent to.

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: Ha! dear Betty, tell her who I am.— Now for an Air of Gravity, and quite another humour, than what I have shown to her Name-sake, lest they shou'd find me out by description.

div.stage: Enter Elder Clerimont, Belvoir, and Mrs. Clerimont.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: — is it? Cousin, your most Humble [Betty whispers Mrs. Clerimont.] Servant— I ask your pardon a thousand times, for my neglect to wait on you. I have design'd it every Day; but—

sp.speaker: L. Land.
sp.p: No Excuse, good Madam; Ladies in this Town have too much Bus'ness on their hands, to throw an hour upon a Thing so insignificant, as a Country Relation; one so remote too, that only claims that Honour by Marriage.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Nay Madam—

sp.speaker: L. Land.
sp.p: Besides, had you given your self the trouble, 'twou'd have been but one, I am sure; for my Conversation is only praises of the Country; raving at every diversion here, because I understand it not; my discourse leaping perpetually into Yorkshire, and talking for ever of my Turkies, my Dairy, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: [aside] Hey! What Maggot's this?— then am I the most deceiv'd in the appearance of a Woman, that ever I was in my Life.

sp.speaker: Eld. Cler.
sp.p: A Shroud Gentlewoman this! I like her mainly: pray Mrs. what made you come to London then?

sp.speaker: L. Land.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, 'twas bus'ness, Monies left in Banker's hands, by my Dear Husband Deceas'd— Oh!

sp.speaker: Eld. Cler.
sp.p: Good Soul! she Weeps! so Young, and Weep for a Dead Husband? Good Soul!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Melancholy Suits ill with such Charming Youth: Cousin, you have been Unfortunately by your Affairs driven into a House, the Rendezvous of Fops, and senseless Cocquets, who have entertain'd you with pleasures so insipid, they have given you a disgust to those more refin'd, that will reconcile you to the Pretty Epitome of our English World the Town.

sp.speaker: Eld. Cler.
sp.p: Marry gap! dan't spoil the Genltewoman, Coz, Mahaps she likes the Country best, why so do I; no offence, I hope Coz.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: We must not suffer so fair an Enemy. The Play-house, Hide-Park, every thing shall contribute to force a kinder Opinion from you.

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: I have seen it all, and despise it: At the Theatre, am tir'd with the double Acted Farce on the Stage, and in the side Boxes; the Noisy Nonsense of the Pit; the Impudence of the Orange Women renders the whole Entertainment to me, a disagreeable Medley: Then, for Hide-Park, that's Madness in perfection; and the poor Lunatick that runs an eternal Circle in his Bedlam Apartment, has, in my Judgement, equal Pleasure.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Oh fy, my Lady Landsworth, this cannot be your real thoughts.

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: To a Tittle, I assure ye.

sp.speaker: Eld. Cler.
sp.p: I fackings, the young Woman speaks rarely: why Toby, she has run down the Lonnoners— Toby! a Lard! where is Toby and the Two Dogs? So ho, so ho!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Peace, good Cousin; I believe they are at the Park-Gate.

sp.speaker: Eld. Cler.
sp.p: O my Man? my Dogs? where are they? I shall run Mad! So ho, Toby!

sp.speaker: L. Lands. Mrs. Betty,
sp.p: let's steal off; I think I have dissembl'd enough for one Day.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: And I hear you have been met with too— I follow Madam.

sp.speaker: Elder Cler.
sp.p: Why Toby! I say Toby! Speak to thy nown Master, Toby!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Come, Sir; we shall find 'em out.

sp.speaker: Elder Cler.
sp.p: Ah never, I fear: Toby, Toby!

div.stage: Enter Toby, with his Head broke.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: What ails ye to Baul so? D'ye zee how I have been serv'd! I went to come in with my Hounds, and an ugly Fellow in Red knockt me down, and took the poor Curs from me.

sp.speaker: Eld. Cler.
sp.p: Ay ye Coward! where was the Quarter-staff?

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Why, he had a Sword; zee how my Head's broke.

sp.speaker: Eld. Cler.
sp.p: I had rather thy Neck were broke than my Dogs lost.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Zome wiser than some: Zo had not I— goa out yonder, and ha'um agen for a Tester.

sp.speaker: Eld. Cler.
sp.p: Go then! Farewal, Cos, You ne'er bring me hither again I'se warrant.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Let's after, we must not part thus; and as we go, I'll tell ye my Opinion of my Lady Landsworth.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I confess she is past my apprehension.

div.stage: Enter Sir John Roverhead and Chris.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: With much ado, I have broke from the Widow; I appointed to meet here the prettiest Rose-bud; if her Fortune equals the Widow, she secures me.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Ah Sir! I wish the common Fortune-Hunter's Fate be not yours, to take the worst at last.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Fool! that Genius that raised me to this, will, no doubt, preserve me conspicuous; the Ornament of the Town, and Idol of the Ladies. You must know Dunce, I love the Young Creature, I am to meet now; and I'de Marry the Widow.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Why then I shou'd think you lik'd her.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Incorrigible Sot! I hate her as the Devil— but has she not Five Thousand a Year? let that, for ever, stop thy Mouth.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Then 'tis the Five Thousand a Year you'd Marry— I ha' done, Sir, I ha' done.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: She comes; remember I am the Lord— the Title will strike an awe into her, and make her refuse me Nothing.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But d'ye think he'l come, Governess?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: I hope his Lordship will.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: His Lordship! that sounds purely: I vow my Aunt will Love me, when I am a great Lady— look— here he is Governess— Oh Gemini! 'tis a dear Man.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: My little Angel! this was kind! the place appear'd Gloomy as Shades beneath, till your bright Eyes, exceeding the Stars, created a double Day.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: O la! What fine Words he has! Sir— My Lord I mean— I am a foolish Girl, and know not how to answer, but I am Young, and not unapt to learn.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Nay, I'll say that for Miss— she was ever as forward as the best of 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Pretty Innocence! She shall not want Instructions Modell'd by me, the World will own her perfect.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: And truly, my Lord, she has enough to pay her Teacher.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Hold, hold! Name not Wealth; 'tis a Dross I despise,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Fie, Governess! Do you think his Lordship Values Money?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Not I, upon my Honor.
(Aside to) Chris. Get it out of the Old One, what she's worth; lest it prove not worth my while to follow her any longer.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, yes.

sp.speaker: Lucind.
sp.p: Now, my Lord, the reason why I have a mind to be Married, is, because I may have a little more freedom. I never go any where now, but that Old Woman's at my heels; and I have heard 'em say, Wives go where they will and do what they will.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: So sha't thou, my dear Miss— [Aside.] Marry, quotha; more Words than One to that Bargain.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But when will you meet me here agen then, and Run away with me? For I was told, I shou'd be Run away with: They say, most Fortunes are.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: to Sir John. Sir— Twenty Thousand Pounds, when she is at Age.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: (Aside) Very well! Gad I'le Marry her; by that time, I shall have spent it; broke her Heart; and be ready for another— My dear Blossom, how happy am I to have gain'd your Affections! Tho' 'tis no wonder; for the Universality of Women dye for me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: For my part, you spoke to me, for that I like ye; else, truly Mr.— (pish, my Lord—) I see as fine things walk here, as you.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Oh fie!

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: This is true Nature, a Baby indeed; she has not yet learnt to Dissemble.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Can ye get out in a Morning, my Dear?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, any time; I am left wholly to my Governess, and you won her heart, t'other Morning with some Sack; promise her some more, and she'l bring me, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: There's that will buy Sack: Will ye bring Miss to Morrow, by Five-a-Clock?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Yes, yes, she shall wait on your Honour, no Body minds us▪ at Home: But we'l serve e'm a Trick.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, Mrs. Rich, and the Company you left, are just coming into this Walk.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: My Dear, Dear, farewel!— One of my Relations, that I dare not see— Farewel this Instant— keep these Verses to remember me; and to Morrow—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh Gemini! If I forget, I'l be hang'd— I shan't sleep all Night for thinking on't. Good b' ye '— Is he not a pure Man, Nurse?

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Ay, marry is he— they shan't think to thrust us up in a Garret; we'l ha' Money, and good things, as well as your proud Aunt, and her Folks.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh la; Mum! here's my Aunt and all they upon our Backs; what shall we say now.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Rich, Lady la Basset, and Mrs. Trickwel.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: This was furiously odd; to desert us only with the Whim to show us Airs in Bowing, when we meet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh la! [furiously] there's a hard Word! I'll learn my Aunt's Words that I may appear agreeable to my Lord— furiously— remember, Governess!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Mrs. Tickwel, I am sick of the Park; here's neither the Beaux nor the Bellemond. Really when Sir John's gone we search in Vain for Gallantry or a good appearance.

sp.speaker: La Bass.
sp.p: I wonder how he durst quit the place, when I was here.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: You!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trick.
sp.p: Upon my Life, Madam, the Ladies are all Mad for this miracle of a Knight: I wish your Ladyship had him fix'd in the Matrimonial Noose, that the rest may burst with Envy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Fear not Mrs. Trickwel, I have him with a double Chain; Love and Interest— ha! This Impertinent Girl here!

sp.speaker: Lucind.
sp.p: Pray don't be angry, Aunt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: In the first place, leave off that word Aunt; and make use of Madam: Or, stay at home with your Father.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: But Aunt, since you are my Aunt, Why may I not call you Aunt?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Why, I being a Woman of Quality, and you but a Citizen's Daughter, I cannot, in decency, be your Aunt, without degrading my self in some measure.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh, good Aunt, let not that concern you, For I shall be a Woman of Quality too in a little time.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: What says the Girl?

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: 'Tis in my power to be as great a Lady as you, Aunt, at least.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Child!

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: I am acquainted with a Lord; the handsomest. and most obliging in the World. I have met him several times in the Park; and he'l Marry me when I please— therefore never trouble your self, Aunt, about my Quality.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: And what's this Lord's Name?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: They call him my Lord Fourbind; he's very Rich, and of great Quality, for he told me so.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Truly, Niece, I am very well pleas'd, that, notwithstanding the mean Education your Father bestow'd on you, you have thoughts worthy the honour I do you, of suffering you to be my Niece; and you are oblig'd to me, and my Conversation for this.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I have another Obligation to desire, Aunt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: To Marry as soon as 'tis possible, if you please Aunt, the Gentleman you Love, that it may Countenance my Marriage with him I Love; that when my Father wou'd chide me, I may answer him, I have not done worse than my Aunt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trick.
sp.p: You'r in the Right— what a terrible thing is Example!

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: But my Aunt must make what hast she can; my Lord Fourbind, my Lover, is most furiously impatient.

sp.speaker: Mrs▪ Rich.
