sp.p: Ah! Mrs. Trickwel! Now can I be reveng'd of Mr. Rich! His Daughter is in Love with a Courtier, and a Courtier with her; and she's Distracted to be Marry'd to him— if the Father and Mother wou'd but dye with Vexation, I shou'd be rid of troublesom Creatures.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trick.
sp.p: But, Madam, are you resolv'd to assist your Niece in her Design;

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Certainly. And I wou'd not for a Thousand Pound, lose this excellent occasion of sending Mr. Rich. to Bedlam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trick.
sp.p: That is very charitable, truly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Come Ladies; let's home to Dinner; this News has pleas'd me.
sp.l: My Niece, and I, will the Example lead,
Teach City-Dames the way to mend their Breed,
Chuse for our selves; let our dull Parents pray;
Devoutly Cheat; each others Lives betray:
And whilst they Drudge, we'l briskly throw away.

div.head: ACT IV.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: WHat a Wretch am I! Forsook by Fate; abandon'd to Want and Misery; my Soul deny'd to use her Faculty; no generous Power to to help the Afflicted; and, as if this were not enough, my Virtue too, the last Stake that I cou'd boast of, is going! I love this vitious Creature, in spite of all her Crimes. Her Charms have won my Heart. Begon, thou soft Intruder; thou effeminate Passion, only sit for lazy Minds. Have I not Wracks without thee, to keep me waking? S'Death! What a Dog I am! Going to be kept by a vile Prostitute! her Drudge; unkennell'd for a Fop, Lord, or some wealthy Fool; sent to my Post of Watching! Confusion! I'l not indure it!

div.stage: Enter Belvoir, Mrs. Clerimont and Jack.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: There he is; I must not be seen.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: My dearest Friend! my Clerimont! What have I done to merit this Unkindness? Why do'st thou shun those Friends, who fondly Love thee? This Lady, your Relation, begs to Serve ye.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Alas! I am Infectious! The detested Plague Poverty's upon me! The meagre Fiend approaches fast, with her Attendants, Starving and Rags! She'l render me so odious, I shall fly, if possible, my self!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Better Fortune waits to Crown your Virtues; believe me, Cousin, it does: Your Brother's in Town; at my House; send to him.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: What, to be Answer'd as I was last: If I wou'd be his Bailiff, I might eat: Curses, I'de sooner feed on my own Flesh! Sue to him, who never knew Humanity!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Well; grant him a Churl; there are a thousand Ways besides to advance your Fortune.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: None, but such as I despise.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Allow me one Request; give me your Company this day, and submit to my Contrivance; I have Thoughts at work, that may produce your future peace.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: My Friend, I am sure, us'd to have more Complaisance, than to deny a Lady.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: I am at your dispose; but remember, Madam, nothing shall tempt me for Bread to do an ill thing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Nor wou'd I offer it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Come with us then; and shake off these melancholy Looks.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Impossible!— Jack:

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Stay you at home; and, d'ye'hear— if any Messages come.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: I shall, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Come, Sir, uncloud that Brow; we won't leave you in Despair▪ tho' we found you so.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Your kindness comes too late:
sp.l: For if ye cou'd the weight of Fate remove:
I'm Dasht agen; and Curst with guilty Love.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Landlady! Landlady!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fidg.
sp.p: Why, how now Impudence! D'ye think you are in an Alehouse?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: I humbly beg your pardon, Sweet Madam Fidget.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fidget.
sp.p: Well, 'tis your Ignorance, I excuse it: What Humour's your hopeful Master in now?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: O these were his Relations, I hope all will be amended: But, Landlady▪ humph, Madam, there's a Plot you and I must carry on for his good.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fidget.
sp.p: With all my heart, I love a Plot extreamly, I was ever good at Plotting: But, dear Brother Plotter, let us do nothing rashly.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: What, a Glass of Sack first; ye shall have it, ye shall have it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fidget.
sp.p: Truly, it helpeth Invention.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Come here's prosperity to our honest Endeavours.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fidget.
sp.p: With all my Spirit.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: 'Tother Glass to the Success.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fidget.
sp.p: Agreed; now let me know it.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: There's a Lady in Love with my Master.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fidget.
sp.p: What, she that call'd in the Coach?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fidget.
sp.p: By my troth! a lovely Woman; that there may come no worse news to England; fill my Glass, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Now this Lady is not a Whore, nor a Married Woman, nor a Widow, nor a Maid—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fidget.
sp.p: I understand ye.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: D'ye, faith; why, what is she, say you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fidget.
sp.p: A kept Mistress, fool.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Right, egad; well, these Londoners are plaguy sharp, we shou'd ne're have guess'd in the Country: This Damsel is worth Thousands, and she'd fain throw away some upon my Master: he, modest Fool, (begging his pardon) he'le none on't, forsooth. So I, being cunning, have found out her Humour by her Appurtenance, her Waiting Gentlewoman, and Lyed my Master into her good Graces; told her he was a meer Debauche; she partly believ'd me, but comes to you to be confirm'd; if you can lye, Landlady.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fidget.
sp.p: Mistrust me not, Jack, I warrrnt ye; but if he won't stand to it, what signifies our Promises.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Oh, 'twill create a longer Acquaintance, and truly I'le get some Money out of her, if he won't; we must not perish; nor will I forsake him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fidget.
sp.p: Well, I'le do my best in an honest way.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Hark, a Coach stops, bring 'em up to show your China, and I'le be there to confirm what you say.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fidget.
sp.p: I run.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: 'Tis a delicate Age, by Gingo, when the Rake is the fine Gentleman; and the fine Gentleman is the Lady's Favourite, egad. Mum, she comes.

div.stage: Re-enter Mrs. Fidget, with Lady Landsworth and Mrs. Betty.

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: Where d'ye Lead me, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fidget.
sp.p: O, I always keep my best China in my Chambers.

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: This looks like a Gentleman's Lodging.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fidget.
sp.p: 'Tis so, but he's very rarely in 'em; he lay Abroad last night, and sent word he shou'd not be at home till Twelve this night. I have a sad hand with him; here's his Man at home, if any of your Misses shou'd send to him; he has forty Ladies, I think, after him. I must give him Warning, my House will be Scandalous else; tho' 'tis a good natur'd Wretch, and can look as demure, I warrant, when a body chides him as any Saint; nay, to some he'le carry himself like one too.

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: (Aside to▪ Betty.) O horrid, let us be gone, my Ears are blasted!

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I cou'd have told you as much, but durst not; you seem'd to be well assur'd.

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: Dissembling Wretch! yet I will see him once agen, then in my own freedom be safe, innocent, and far from this bewitching Town, pass my days serenely; nor think of false Mankind, nor trust; and therefore be deceiv'd no more. (to Jack.) Well, then there's no probability of seeing your hopeful Master to day.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Yes, Yes Madam, I can find him in a minute, when the Summons is to a fair Lady.

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: That's well, thou art a diligent Servant.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Aye, Madam, tho' I say it, I am fit to be e're a Gentleman's Pimp in England, and that's a bold word, now.

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: Excellent Office; pray, Mr. Pimp, then do me the favour to tell your Master, I'le be here at Five-a-Clock, to look on some China.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: It shall be done, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fidget.
sp.p: If he forgets, fear not Madam, I'le remember.

sp.speaker: L. Lands.
sp.p: No doubt on't, you have a noble Vocation too, I suppose, tho' it has but a course Name; come Betty, farewell, at night I'le chuse some China.

sp.speaker: Fidget.
sp.p: You are very Welcome, Madam.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: What think ye now, Madam Fidget?

sp.speaker: Fidget.
sp.p: Faith, I know not what to think, her Looks were cold and scornful.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Pho, Pho, she's as wanton and warm as er'e a one of your Daughters, after a zealous Fit of Devotion.

sp.speaker: Fidget.
sp.p: Impudence! how dare you mention my Daughters so irreverently.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Nay, no harm; come let's in, and take a Glass to clear our Understanding, and ripen our Plot.

sp.speaker: Fidget.
sp.p: You are an unlucky Dog, I see it in your Face, and will never bring it to any thing.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Thou art Old enough to be a Prophetess, only Truth and you were at mortal Odds, ever since you eat Chalk and Tobacco pipes.

sp.speaker: Fidget.
sp.p: Thou art a Rogue, but Sack shall attone.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Come then.

div.stage: Scene change to Mrs. Rich's House.
Enter Mrs. Rich, Lady La Basset and Mrs. Trickwell.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Here, Fellows, stand at all your several Posts, and let the World know I am at home: I will appear in State.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trick.
sp.p: Why does not your Ladyship establish your Visiting-days?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: I have Mrs. Trickwell, and the rude Town takes no Notice of 'em; wou'd you believe it, I have sat ye five, six hours, and not a Soul, but an ill-bred Citizen's Wife, whose unconscionable Visit lasted the whole time, and her whole Discourse, let me dye, of the awkward Brutes, her Children: A my Soul they were begot by her Husband, the things were so ungenteel.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trick.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, what a prodigious deal of Wit your Ladyship has.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: So amongst our selves, I think too; yet wou'd you believe that ill-manner'd Oaf, my Husband's Brother, had the confidence to tell me the envious World said I was a Fool, my Lady Basset, a Fool, wou'd you believe it; I say, that Parts, and sheer Wit, cou'd be so malign'd.

sp.speaker: La Basset.
sp.p: 'Tis a censorious World. (Aside.) I begin to hate her, tho' I win her Money, now she's likely to get Sir John from me.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: O Mame, your La ' Ships humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: So, that's pretty well; give your self Airs, Child, When I admit ye into my Company: Umph! pluck up your head: What! no motion with your Fan: Ah, 'tis awkward, but sure, by my Example, she'l learn.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trick.
sp.p: To be redicuous. (Aside.) Mind your Aunt, Miss, if you'd be the Emblem of Perfection.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Fie, fie, Mrs. Trickwell, you flatter me.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: O la, I can't make my Fan do like my Aunt's.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: O my Stars! she'l make a horrid Person of Quality: But prithee, Neice, how dost thou know this Lord loves thee, hey.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Oh Mame, he has told me so, and my Governess says 'tis unmannerly not to believe a Lord; besides, he makes Verses on me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Verses, O my Stars! what a Theme he has chose; let's see 'em.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Here, Aunt, they be pure Verses; there's a hugeous deal of Love in 'em.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.l: I love you, charming Fair one, more
Then ever Mortal lov'd before.
And tho', to my surprizing Joy,
The little, wanton, bearless Boy
Has heard my Prayers, and made you feel,
The amorous sharpness of his Steel;
Confusion seize me, if my heart,
Don't with a mightier Passion smart.

sp.speaker: La Bass.
sp.p: What do I hear! (Aside) And have you the Impudence to say this Poetry was design'd for you!

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Mame!—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Monkey, the Girl has stolen 'em out of my Cabinet.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Aunt—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Hold your peace, be gone, and let me never see that young bewitching Face again.

sp.speaker: La Bass.
sp.p: I can hold no longer, the Verses belong to me.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: The Verses belong to you! that's furiously impossible, as my Aunt says; how should my Lord know you, to make Verses of you; you may look high indeed, but not so high as a Lord, sure.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: But my Stars that's well enough; have I not bid ye go, ye little Impertinence; there must be some Mistake.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: There must so, Mame, I warrant your Lover has begg'd 'em of my Lord, and given 'em you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Unlucky Creature, will ye go?

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Yes. I'le find my dear Lord, and ask him: Not that I care for the Verses, so I have the Man.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: What a Confusion I am in; if I break with Lady Basset, she may expose my foibless to the whole Town; and to brook a Rival—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trick.
sp.p: Observe how Mrs. Rich is disturb'd; here we shall lose a Bubble for your foolish Love affair.

sp.speaker: La Bass.
sp.p: Confound her! have I kept Sir John, and run all the Risques in the Universe to maintain his Port, and shall he dare Address without my Leave.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trick.
sp.p: 'Twas ever so, Lady Basset; we little Ones doat upon the handsome Footman first; make a hard shift to Equip him, then some topping Dame swoops the drest up Fellow, and he forgets his Original.

sp.speaker: La Bassat.
sp.p: I'll lower his Top-Sail! and make him know he's mine, and only mine.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Is it any happy thing we know▪ my Lady! that has the Honour to be yours, and only yours.

sp.speaker: La Basset.
sp.p: Yes verily, a thing you are fond off, and to convince ye how vain all your hopes are, know he Sacrifices all his Fools to me! here's a List of 'em, chaw upon't and Farewell!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Mondieu! she has won three Hundred Pound of my Money, and now she Picks a Quarrel with me. Civil I protest.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trick.
sp.p: Ungrateful Wretch! should I forsake my Friend!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Never whilst they have Three Hundred Pound left! 'tis against the Rule of Prudence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trick.
sp.p: Alass Madam, what d'ye mean?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Your Pardon Mrs. Trickwell! I mean nothing; I am angry with the whole World, will Indulge my ill Nature, and never bless 'em with a smile agen.

sp.speaker: Mr. Trick.
sp.p: I thought your Ladyship wou'd have allow'd your Lover to have been beloved.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: But not to Love, ' there's the Destinction. To increase my spleen, let's see what this Fury has left!
sp.stage: A List of the Fools that doat on my proper person. So.
sp.p: Dorimene the Back-biter, at the Gilt-Post in Twatling Square; Very well.
The Rich Amorous Banker's Widow, removed from behind the Exchange, at the Citizens Folly, into Covent-Garden. Oh! how I hate my self, for having loved him.
Miranda the Gilt in Scotland-yard. Arabella the Affected▪ in Pride Lane, at the Dressing Box.
The Lady Hazard, under the Doctors care in Covent-Garden, at the Magdalene▪ He's a Monster.
The Fat Marchioness, with her Shinning Face, near the Red-House in Plaisterstreet. Villain, I'll see him no more. Betty.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: 'Tis resolved on: I'le see Sir John no more.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I believe I hear him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Whither do you go?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I'me going to meet him, Madam, to tell him you'l see him no more.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: No, no, Betty, let him come in, I will confound him, and see with what Impudence he'l justify this List.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Here he is, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ah! are you there, Madam? you cannot imagine my impatience till I see you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: From what quarter of the Town come you, Sir? from Twatling Square? or Covent-Garden? or is it the Rich Amorous Banker you left last?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I know not what you mean, Madam!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Not what I mean, perfidious Man?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Upon my Honour, Madam, I do not understand you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: See the Obliging List of your Fools Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, and has this discompos'd your La'ship; only a Frolick at my Lady Jeerwells: We were all set to abuse our Friends; a Lady put down her List, and writ me the Leading Coxcomb, at which we laugh'd for half an hour. I never knew your Ladyship so out in the practice of Quality in my whole life: Why, the Wit of the Age lies in Abuses. I warrant ye, there's my Lady Toss●um did a thousand rediculous things, and at last cry'd for very Vexation, that none of the Scriblers wou'd put her in Rhime Dogrel.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: I fear I'me in the wrong, Mrs. Trickwell.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trick.
sp.p: I fear so to; Sir John is nice, at these things extreamly nice.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Aye, but the Verses, Mrs. Trickwell.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trick.
sp.p: The Verses, Sir John, the Verses.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Why, that was the very Adventure I was coming to laugh with your Ladyship about: I must confess I was indiscreet enough to communicate; my Heart and Tongue being full of my Passion, I went, Madam, to the Chocolate-house, where I met five or six Wits; Yes, Madam, five or six; and let not that astonish you, for we live in a very fertile Age for Wits.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: And what then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What then, Madam? Why, they told me, how that my Lord Four●ines had given these Verses to a Citizen's young Daughter; that Mr. Flutter had sent them to a She Friend of his; that, Sir Richard Welbred had obtain'd favours from his Mistress by these Verses, ha, ha, ha, ha. Is not this diverting, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: So, I suppose, you are extreamly vain, and pleas'd to see your Works thus Universal.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trick.
sp.p: As we are, Madam, we leaders of the Town, and fronters of the Boxes, when we find a Fashion begun by us, awkardly aim'd at by all the little Pretenders to Dress.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: When, alass, borrow'd Wit, like borrow'd Cloaths, sits none but the Owners: To you, and you alone, the Song is a propos; my Heart is only sensible of so much Fire, your Eyes have only power thus to inspire.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trick.
sp.p: How full of Tenderness is all Sir John says. (Aside.) I shall deserve the Five hundred Pounds, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: I grant his Expressions are full of Douceurs; but then he wants Sincerity and Truth, Mrs. Trickwell.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trick.
sp.p: Truth, in a Compliment, or Courtier, oh fie Madam! 'tis against the Nature of the thing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Why, de la Bet, how charmingly contrary is this to my City-education: But canst thou believe Sir John's in love with ought but that dear Shadow of his, which he's Caressing so passionately in the Glass.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I dare swear that's his Idol; but your Ladyship will not hear me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Yes Betty, I shall take a time, for I am vex'd, but scorn to show ●●▪

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Madam—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Peace, see, and admit 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: [Setting his Wig in the Glass.] Pax of this ill-favour'd Curl, how many Hairs it exceeds his fellows; this Monsieur Cheuruex is a Booby, Demme.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: How Concern'd Sir John is, in his Justification, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trick.
sp.p: (Aside.) This Fool will lose his Opportunity, and I my Money: the Glass robs us of your Conversation, Sir John▪

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: No, 'tis the Lady robs me of my self; I am perpetually studying new Airs only to please her.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Madam, Mrs. Clerimont, and a world of Company to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Oh my Stars, and are the Indian Curtains drawn, the Wax Candles ready, the Keys with the gold Strings in the Cabinet-doors.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, all is in order.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Why, Tam, Ralph, Waitwell.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: So, the Fit of Vanity returns, (Aside.) they are, Madam, where you Commanded 'em.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Oh Heavens! now Sir John shou'd be caught saying fine things to me, and he's practising Grimaces in the Glass.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trick.
sp.p: Sir John, here's Visiters to the Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ha! where? Be near me Chriss. we will receive 'em.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich▪
sp.p: Shall I be laughing, or in a Passion, or how, dear Mrs. Trickwell▪ quick, quick, your Instructions: Some say I become a Passion rarely.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trick.
sp.p: In no Passion, I beseech you, Madam, but that of Joy to see your Friends: Look, they are here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Well, I'le be advis'd; but my City Neighbours sed I chid my Maids with such a Grace, they'd have given all the World to have done like me.

div.stage: Enter Belvoir, Elder Clerimont, Mrs. Clerimont and Toby.

sp.speaker: Eld. Cler.
sp.p: A near place this, Toby; but our House i'th' Country was nigh as hansome, till the Hounds, and my Hunts-folks tore it about.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Aye Master, but ye had not near so much Earthen Ware, that ye had not, ad our Mopsa wou'd make rare work we it; Udsnigs she wou'd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Why, Mr. Bellvoir, I am baulk'd in my design of my Visit; I intended to have brought the Younger Clerimont, and the Lady Landsworth, to an interview; and his Man has Whisked him away just as we came out of the Coach.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: We must on now, there's no retreating; they look as if they had been setting themselves this hour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: I have a sudden whim, prithee assist.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What is't?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: I'le make my Lubberly Cozen pass upon that Fantastick Creature, for a Beau in disguise.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That's an odd fancy indeed, surely 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Sir John! is this the Mode of the Wits, to come into ones House, ann find all the Discourse among themselves.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I am in a Maze, Madam! let us Accost 'em.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: If you please give me leave Sir John, what Honours are these ye heap upon me, Ma'me; to receive a Visit from the Charming Mrs. Clerimont!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Charms and Perfections, loose their Signification, when applyed to any, where Mrs. Rich is by.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Oh, Madam—

sp.speaker: Eld. Cler.
sp.p: Aye, Toby, here's Words; I brought thee in to learn a little.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Udsnigs, 'tis rare, Master.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Mr. Belvoir, I cast me at your Feet.

sp.speaker: Belvoir.
sp.p: Sir John, I kiss your hands.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: [To Cler.] Sir, I am Yours.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Nouns, what's he a going to do, unbuckle Master's Shooe.

sp.speaker: Eld. Cler.
sp.p: What a plague; ye have run your Mop in my Face, and e'ne choak'd me with your Powder.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: A hey! the meaning of this, my dear Belvoir?

sp.speaker: Belvoir▪
sp.p: An uncommon Fancy, Sir John, you cannot find out, I perceive.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Poyson me, 'twas the oddest Reception! for Pluto's sake, what is he?

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: What is he? Why he is my Master, Udsnigs! dant provoke en, he'le have a Game at Fifty Coffs we ye, as well as e're a Man in Vorty Mile on him.

sp.speaker: El. Cler.
sp.p: Let'n alone Toby, 'tis another Oth Libken Souls, a high Wind, or a Shower firights into Fits of the Mother: I dispise en.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Oh my Stars! who has your Ladyship got with yee?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Let me beg your private Ear; that Man is the greatest Nicest Beau in Christendom.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Ye amaze me Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Very true upon my Word. That fellow there, that looks so like a John-a Nokes, is the Jemmest Valet; a Countess has been in Love with him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: O my Stars, can I believe you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cle.
sp.p: You may, no Creture knows it but my self, I beg ye keep it a secret, especially from Sir John, or murder will ensue.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: I engage, oh I love a secret extremely, but what could be the occasion?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cle.
sp.p: A Lady affronted him, and he swore never to address again, but in this strange disguise, because his Mistress chose his rival only for having his Wigg better powder'd, he'll not alter this behaviour, nor dress, till some other Lady makes him amends. He's my relation, I wonder you can't perceive some Airs of greatness thro those Clouds.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Not I, I protest, but the more naturally he does it, he shows his parts the more.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cle.
sp.p: He calls his Gentleman Toby. Cou'd you think one bred a Page had power to put on such a shuffling Gate?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: 'Tis a diverting whimsie now one knows it; He, he, he!

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Won't ye give me leave to laugh with ye, Ladies, at those strange figures? I beg it of ye, for I am ready to burst.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: It may be dangerous, Sir John, and I advise you to keep your countenance. How pretty 'tis to know a thing the rest of the Company does not?

sp.speaker: El. Cle.
sp.p: Come Cuz, what must we do next, we ha' stared about us long enough, Madam. Ha'yee ne're a Smoaking Room, and a Cup of hearty March, ha—

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Ay fackins, had Master and I been at e're a Gentleman's house i'th' Country, by this time we had been half Seas-over, Udsnigs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Rarely performed I vow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cle.
sp.p: Now must I keep up the humour, and pretend to direct him. Fie Cousin, talk of drinking before Ladies, you shou'd entertain them with fine Conversation and Songs.

sp.speaker: El. Cle.
sp.p: I dan't pass, and I do gi' yee a Song; come a Hunting Song.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Better and better, by my Stars.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: She seems pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trick.
sp.p: I am in the dark.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Excellent! abominable.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cle.
sp.p: Now if you please, Madam, we'll pay a Visit to my Lady Landsworth; my Cousin said he wou'd return.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Withal my heart, I believe she's not at home, but the opportunity will show my apartments.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Madam, my hand.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Your pardon Sir John, this Gentleman's a stranger.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Preferr'd to me!

sp.speaker: El. Cle.
sp.p: Stand by, Muskcat, you see the Gentlewoman likes ye not.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Well done, Master, egad, he'll put by a hundred such Limberham'd Beaus as you, egad, he will cram 'em in a Mouse-hole, I fakings.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cle.
sp.p: Ah poor Sir John, e'en take that tatter'd Frigat and be content.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trick.
sp.p: Lets follow and find out the meaning.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Ye Gods, and Goddesses; Hell, Devils and Furies, I'll be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, what strange Oaths he has?

div.stage: SCENE Change to younger Cleremont's Lodgings.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Where is she! how my desires are changed! Triumphant Love prevails, a thousand fires shot from those fair Eyes have warmed me; a thousand Arguments pleading all for Pleasure, lead me on, the Lord within plants and heaves my bosom, whilst circling tides rowl round a pace, and give tumultuous joys.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Ay marry, Sir, now you look and breath another Man, good fortune is your slave, she always waits upon the bold.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And what know I but the coy Dame, who hides her Face at the least word a wry, and blushes to be gaz'd on, has in her heart looser fires than my gay Mistress. How many an honest wretch that ask'd wou'd swear his Arms infolded a Lucrece, yet truly hugs in the dissembled Saint, a vile Jilt?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Right, Sir, right; oh I cou'd burn my Cap for joy to see you thus.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: She's coming, and seems in busie talk, let us not disturb her.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: As soon as ever my Lady was ingaged, I fled to over-take ye, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Lands.
sp.p: 'Twas kindly done, Yonder he stands, methinks I hate him, now he has lost that modest sweetness which caught my unwary Soul, his looks are wild and lewd, and all I ever fear'd in men appears in that deceitful face: I would I were away.

sp.speaker: Betty,
sp.p: Nay, Madam, make this last trial, since you have gone so far.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: May I yet approach.

sp.speaker: La. Lands.
sp.p: You may, I do remember when we parted last, 'twas on odd terms, nature seemed reverst, you fled and I pursued in vain, I practised all my Charms, and tryed my utmost Art in vain, your Vertue like the Mountain Snow, the nearer I advanced congeal'd the more, and in the bloom of youth, rigid and cold as frozen Age, you awed me with severity. Are ye still thus resolv'd?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Oh no, I am alter'd quite, my very Soul's on fire, do not my Eyes speak for me? I languish, burn and die.

sp.speaker: La. Lands.
sp.p: Then we have conquer'd, and like Libertines we'll rove, tire every Pleasure, tread rounds of joy, the Insipid world shall wonder at, but never know to taste.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Nay, we shall live a delicious life that's certain, ha my dear Damsel.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Peace, and mind your betters.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What musick's in that voice, it dances thro my ears▪ and puts my heart in tune: not painted Cherubs, not the first dawn of chearful day, or opening Spring is half so pleasing. Oh thou art Rapture all, and all Divine, down at thy lov'd sight each Sense drinks deep draughts of joy.

sp.speaker: La. Lands.
sp.p: Throw off these mourning weeds, and let me dress thee extravagant as my desires, like a Queen's favourite, for I wou'd be profuse.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Lard, Lard, how fine we shall be.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: If there must be profusion, let it be in Love; there lay out all thy Stock; let days and nights and years serve only to count the acts of Love.

sp.speaker: La. Lands.
sp.p: Yes, and teach us to deceive my Keeper, his Purse must help our Riots, his Credulity supply our Mirth.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Ah, why hast dash'd my rising Extasies with the detested thought that thou art shar'd, but in thy Arms I'll lose the goading torment; in those blissful moments I'm sure thou art only mine, my Life, my All

sp.speaker: La. Lands.
sp.p: Stand off, thou Monster, viler, worse than Man, let thy Contagious breath infect at distance. I will remove thee from my sight, and from my Soul, as far as thou art gone from Honour, Truth and Honesty.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Here's a turn ye Gods, why what's the matter now?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Madam—

sp.speaker: La. Lands.
sp.p: Speak not, nor dare to stay me, for I'll leave thee like thy good Genius in thy distressful hours, never to return. Oh I cou'd Curse my self, my Follies, to believe there was Vertue in thy Sex, thou vile dissembler: May it return upon thee; dissembled be thy Joys; dissembled be thy Friends; above all may thy Mistress prove the Abstract of Dissimulation.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Hear me but speak.

sp.speaker: La. Lands.
sp.p: No, hast thee to some Mart of Luxury and Shame, Preach there, but defile my ears no more; away, my Friends, away,
sp.l: Let's fly that wretch, fly him and all mankind:
Now for the Curst pursuer leave a track behind.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What's the meaning of all this?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Mad, Sir, raving Mad.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Can she be honest?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Impossible, had she the roguish Lear, the Tip, the Wink, the every thing.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Peace raskal, she is, and not the world shall hide her from me.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Now must we go upon Knight Errantry; nay heaven be prais'd, we are as poor as Knight Errants already.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Fly, Search, Inquire.
sp.l: She cannot, must not long remain unknown,
She'll be discover'd by her Charms alone,
I'll find, I'll claim, I'll seize her for my own,
Breath at her feet my Vows, nor thence remove,
Till I am blest with her returning Love.

div.head: ACT V.
div.stage: Enter Clerimont, Mrs. Fidget and Jack.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p:
SUre 'twas all a Dream, I neither saw nor lik'd, nor lov'd; it was a Dream, the Gaudy Vision's vanish'd, and I am waked again to my calamities; or grant it real, what had I to do with Love? Loves the gay Banquet of luxurious hours, he shakes his golden wings, and flies detested
Poverty, To downy Couches, under gilded roofs he flies, There lays his wanton head, there revels in the fair ones Eyes.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Sir, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: When the poor joyn they hardly taste a night of Peace: Strife traces Hymens steps so close, the haggard thrusts between at Bed, at Board and drives the gentle God away. Oh! my distracted thoughts: Why do ye follow me? Is misery denied the privelege to be alone?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fid.
sp.p: Ah, Sir, 'tis that unlucky dog your Man has done this.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Hist!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fid.
sp.p: Nay, it shall out.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What has he done? Speak!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fid.
sp.p: Why, Sir—

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Peace, I say, ye ungrateful Cockatrice; now will not all the Sack I have ramm'd down that unconscionable throat keep this poor secret in, tho upon my word, I meant it for the best: Believe that, I beseech you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: What's the matter? What have ye said?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fid.
sp.p: Ay, said, there ye have hit it: he has said enough, by my troth.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: I am sure you always say too much.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fid.
sp.p: Say ye so, Sirrah, know then, Sir, that hopeful Rogue gave ye such a Character to the young Gentlewoman, 'twou'd have frighted the Devil.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: And what said you, Mrs. Dalilah?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fid.
sp.p: Even the same, by thy instigation, thou Tempter.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Keep that name to your self, it belongs to you, Woman: I thought, Sir, she lov'd nothing but a Rake, a Madman. I did all for the best, indeed I did, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: No matter; 'tis the malice of my Fate, which wou'd have found an Instrument, hadst thou been silent.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fid.
sp.p: Come, hang Melancholy, and cast away Care; my mind gives me, this Damsel will wheel about agen: I never yet knew Man or Woman weary of an Intrigue, when 'thas gone no further than yours has done.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Right: There ye are in the right, I'faith, Landlady.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fid.
sp.p: Well, sawce, you'll never leave your Impudence. Landlady; Blockhead!

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Thank ye, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Still with folded arms and looks of sorrow. I come to cheer thee, my Friend; to make thee laugh, to give thee lasting joy.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Impossible!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Thy Brother is fallen in Love with the fantastical Widow Rich; her Wealth and Beauty has Charm'd him: Ye know that he is possess'd of a great Estate. He never had management enough to be master of Money, and hearing the Widow has so much he is distracted for't; whilst she takes him for a Beau in Masquerade, is wonderfully pleas'd; and, I believe, will be a Match.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And what's all this to me?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Oh! much to your advantage; for he has promis'd Mrs. Clerimont, if she can bring this Marriage to pass, he will resign that part of the Estate to you, your Father in his life time had design'd ye.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: There thou speak'st comfort that suits my wishes, for I wou'd fain Travel, but want the means.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Travel!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: My Friend, 'tis not Wealth can make me happy now.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Ah, Sir, but Wealth's a good stroak: I see Providence has not quite forgot us.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Whatever you have resolv'd, I beg ye to go this moment with me to Mrs. Clerimont's: A busie minute now is worth a lazy year.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Do even what you please with me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Come on then.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fid.
sp.p: Good luck attend ye.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Rich, and two Footmen.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: I design a Ball to night, sots, and wou'd have, if possible, you Rascals clean; and you, d'ye hear—

sp.speaker: La. Bas.
sp.p: I'll fright this little pretender to Quality, till she either quits Sir John, or buys him of me at a good round rate; he has made many a penny of me, now 'tis time to retaliate. Madam, send off your Footmen; I wou'd speak with ye alone.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: La. Bas.
sp.p: Be gone, Scoundrels, or I shall drive ye hence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Fellows, be near me, I know not what her design is.

sp.speaker: La. Bas.
sp.p: My design is honourable.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Heavens! What can she mean?

sp.speaker: La. Bas.
sp.p: Base Coward, are ye afraid?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Afraid, Madam: I! I—

sp.speaker: La. Bas.
sp.p: Come, no dallying; you have rob'd me of Sir John: I demand satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: O my Stars! This is extravagant to the last degree. Alas, Madam, what satisfaction can a Lady give to a Lady.

sp.speaker: L. Bas.
sp.p: I'd have thee fight. Dare you set up for Quality, and dare not fight, pitiful Citizen: 'Tis for thy honour; 'tis modish too, extreamly French, and agreeable to thy own phrase. I'll have thee fight, I say:

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: What need I, when I have Conquer'd already: Can I help the power of my Eyes, or Sir John's sensibility. My Stars, this is prodigious! What Weapon must we use in this unusual Combat, hey, Madam?

sp.speaker: La. Bas.
sp.p: D'ye make a jest on't. Sword and Pistol, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Oh, Heavens! I swoon at the sight of either.

sp.speaker: La. Bas.
sp.p: Thou art the Off-spring of an Alderman, I of Quality: I can Fight, Ride, Play; equal the Men in any Vertue or Vice. Thou little Creature, yield, or sa, sa— Thus for Sir John: Sa, sa.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: The Woman's mad: Will ye come in my house and murder me?

sp.speaker: La. Bas.
sp.p: Look, is this a Jest?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Murder! Murder. Jack! Geffery! George! Help! Help!

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Hey day! What's the House turn'd into a perfect Bedlam, learning to fence, Madam Whimsical?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Oh, Brother, save me from that furious Woman, and I'll submit, for the future, to your Conduct.

sp.speaker: La. Bas.
sp.p: (aside.) Curse on him; this is a sensible Fellow, and my design's lost.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: And what are you, a Lady Errant, and this the 'Squire of the body: He looks as if he had lived upon Adventures indeed.

sp.speaker: La. Bas.
sp.p: No matter what I am. I am mad.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: I believe so.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: I shan't recover the fright this twelve month.

sp.speaker: La. Bas.
sp.p: She wou'd bea Woman of Quality, and dares not fight: By the honour of my Ancestors, I'll go find out Sir John, and if he does not change his resolution, he and I shall dispute it. Come along, Vermin.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Ha, ha, that wou'd be a pretty Combat, in troth; he dares not fight a Man: This Woman will be an excellent match for him. Dost thou yet see thy folly, thy own, and thy Instructor's folly: These things teach thee to appear like the truly Great. Alas, mistaken wretch, they are as far from noble Natures, as light from darkness.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: I do begin to find my errour, and am mending my Conversation; yet think not, tho' ye have humbled me, you shall e'er bring me back to the City agen▪ No, I have still spirit enough to defie the City, and all its works. By my Stars, I'll never endure a greasie City Feast; a set Custard is my aversion of all aversions, as Olivia has it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible to turn the Current of a Womans Will, tho' it perpetually runs the wrong way.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, such a piece of Treachery, such Perfidiousness have I discover'd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: In whom? My Stars, this is a day of wonders!

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Even Sir John, going from your Ladyship in a huff, because you smil'd upon the worthy Gentleman in disguise; met your Niece; she flew upon him with a violent Exclamation, My Lord Fourbine, your's intirely. He answer'd in a passionate tone, Ah mon cher, I die for ye.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: My Daughter!

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Yes, your Daughter; and together they whisk'd cross the Gallery, to Misses Apartment: I left 'em there, and came to inform your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: 'Tis all Confusion and Amazement!

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: I am destracted! my Daughter: I'll kick him, burn his flaxen Wigg, dirty his white Coat, knock out his butter Teeth, wring off his Nose, and spoil him for being a Beau for ever.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Whilst I conceal my self in one of the Closets, if this be true, Betty, I have such a revenge shall make the Town ring on't.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Do, Madam. (aside to Mr. Rich) Now, Sir, now's the time to clear the house of the Locusts, these swarm of Fools.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Set all thy wits at work, my good girl. Come, shew me this happy couple, I shall spoil their mirth I'gad.

div.stage: Enter Sir John, Lucinda, Chris, and Governess.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Beyond my wish! Mrs. Rich's Niece, the World shall applaud my revenge: But, my dear, are you sure none of the Family will interrupt us.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p:
No, no, they mew me here eternally with that old Woman; my Aunt hates a younger face than her own shou'd appear where she is: I am not such a Child but I can find that. Come hasten, Governess, pack up all my Jewels;
we'll steal out at the back-door, bid adieu to my sweet Aunt, till my dear Lord and I visit her in a Coach and Six.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: That's my Cherubim, help Chris, help, I long to be gone.

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: My Lord, we'll ha down in a twinkling.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: But look you my Lord, I must tell you my mind in two or three words before we go, what you must trust to. Do you see I am not furiously in Love; as my Aunt says, I run away only for more Pleasure, more Liberty, &c. I will go every day to the Play, or else to the Park; and every time I go to the Park, to the Lodge, to Chelsey: In fine, where I please, or as I run away with you, I'll run away from you, sue for my own Fortune again, and live as I please: What I have heard how Ladies with Fortunes do.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: A young Gipsie this, who'd have thought it had been in her, (aside. Mon cher ame, you shall have your will.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: That you must expect, my dear Lord, for had I lov'd obedience I had still obey'd my Father: And she that begins with her Father generally makes an end with her Husband; but that's furiously modish, and therefore so much the better. Quick, quick, good Governess, and then ahey for disobedience.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: And then ahey for disobedience, Who is this, my Daughter, with her ahey for disobedience?

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: O gemini, my Father! what shall I do now! well, I'll e'en turn sides, take my Father's part, if he's uppermost, and rail at my Lord furiously.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Art thou the flaring Fop my hopeful Sister's fond on, descended from thy Dutchess Bed-Chamber, to steal my Daughter?

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: I am a Gentleman, Sir, and expect to be us'd like one.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: 'Tis false, thou art not, I have trac'd thy Original, and found thou art none.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: O la! not a Gentleman, why he swore to me he was a Lord, out upon him.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Well said Miss, I find we may e'en be marching, for any friends we have here. Thou unpolish'd thing, I answer thy Affront, with my Mein, my Dress, my Air, all shew the Gentleman, and give the lye to thy ill mannered Malice.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Defie me, thou thing equip'd! Canst thou justifie the worst of Thefts, stealing my Child? Draw.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Your Pardon, Sir, not before the Lady, I may discompose her, perhaps the sight of a Sword may fright her into a fit.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: O la, don't let me hinder ye.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Art thou not a Fool?

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: A Fool, alamode, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: A Coward.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: I am a Beau, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: All sound and no Sence.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: I sing tolerably well. For who wou'd in a Cellar Dine, when he may go to Locket's.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Thou trifling Coxcomb, all Wig and no Brains, begone this very Instant, or I'll lead thee thus by the Nose, I'll lead thee to a she Fop of thy acquaintance, Coxcomb, I will, therefore make use of thy Heels.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Egad, this is very uncivil.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: I meant it so.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: I'll Lampoon thee, till your Friends shall fly ye, your Neighbours despise ye, and the World laugh at ye.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: I believe your Wit's as dangerous as your Courage, be gone, Insect.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Pretend to be a Lord, and baulk a young Womans expectation!

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Ah poor Sir John, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Has she been a spectator, I shall be jear'd to death, I will study a revenge shall make you tremble, I will, thou barbarous Cit.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Go set your Perriwig to rights fop, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir. Joh.
sp.p: Curses, Curses, Ah I shall Choak.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Farewell fool; you, Madam, I (Exit. Sir John) shall find a time to discourse with; dear Mrs. Betty, take her into your care, whilst I turn this old Limb of Iniquity out of doors; here you had a mind to run away, now I desire you to walk about your business. Be gone thou unnecessary evil.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Let her go, I say, she seduced me I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Oh, fie, fie, Miss.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Begone, 'twas her canting deceiv'd me; what care we ought to take whom we set over our Children. Enter Mrs. Rich. So Madam, are you satisfied.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Rage, Spite, Shame and Resentment at once torment me, so base a Coward, my Stars, I shall go Mad.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Dear Sister, let your Stars alone, and learn to shun folly, wheresoe'er you find it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Then I must shun you, my self and all the World. You have a set and formal folly, I a vain and airy folly, but he the basest, most betraying folly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Then redeem your Judgment, and stop Censorious mouths, by accepting Mrs. Clerimont's Kinsman, whom your Woman tells me has a plenfull Estate, this will turn the Laughter of the Town upon Sir John, and leave you in happy Circumstances.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: I will do something, something to plague that fellow.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Here comes the Lady, I believe to plead in her friends behalf.

div.stage: Enter Lady Landsworth and Mrs. Clerimont.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cle.
sp.p: Ah, Madam, such a misfortune.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: The whole deceitful world, by my Stars, I think is full of nothing else.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cle.
sp.p: But this, Madam, your bright eyes create.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: I my eyes, that's pleasant.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cle.
sp.p: The strictness of his Vow racks him, for he knows a Lady thus Accomplish'd, can never like him as he appears.

sp.speaker: La. Lands.
sp.p: Indeed I pity him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Pray Ladies, what's the Case?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cle.
sp.p: Alas! Sir, a Cousin of mine who wants not the goods of Fortune; but lies under an obligation to seem the greatest Clown in the Universe, till fate has made him reparation for the affront he receiv'd, when all his study was Dress and Conversation.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: And has he a good Estate?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Four thousand a year I assure ye.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Gadzooks, what matter is it where ever he is Drest, as ye call it, again or no.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Yes, yes, that is material upon my word, Mr. Rich.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Would you consent to marry him▪ for so far his Oath extends; believe me, Madam, he'd soon break forth to your amazement.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: I profess Ladies, you give me such an Air of blushing, when I reflect on what ye are tempting me to.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: I profess Mame, 'tis a very becoming Air.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: My Stars! 'twill sound so odd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: 'Twill surprize the Town so prettily.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Zooks, 'tis the best thing to piece up your fantastical Character; 'twill surprize the world indeed to see you do a wise thing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Speak not you, Sir, for I yield only to the Ladies. Well, where is the Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Languishing within, Madam; condemn'd to silence, least his rough hewn expressions shou'd offend.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: De la Bett, a pen and Ink, perhaps I may expose the Knight, and satisfie your friend. Your pardon for some moments; come with me Neece.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, pray let us be reveng'd on this sham Lord, you can't think what a lyar he is.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Your Servant.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Yours.

sp.speaker: La. Lands.
sp.p: Follow Dear De la Bett, as thy Lady has it, and now show thy Master Piece.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: I lay my life 'tis done, I see in her Eyes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: In hopes on't, I'll get a parson. This Widow married, my affairs are prosperous, and my Daughter and her Fortune return to me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Hasten, good Sir, for this fair Lady and I have a little business of our own.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: More Weddings, I hope, then we'll have Dancing in abundance; come honest De la Bett, I promise thee a new portion to thy new name.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: I'll endeavour to deserve it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: My Charming Cousin, have not I found a pretty imployment, to turn general Match-maker?
But for the younger Clerimont, I own I could do any thing.

sp.speaker: La. Lands.
sp.p: I shou'd dissemble worse than I thought he did, not to say I'm pleas'd to find his Character what I so heartily wish'd it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: To convince ye throughly, I have sent for his Landlady, whose odd account of him must proceed from folly, or malice: O here she comes!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Your Servant, Madam, 'twas not for goods, as I pretended I gave you this trouble, but to ask after the deportment of my Relation, Mr. Clerimont, your Lodger.

sp.speaker: La. Lands.
sp.p: The wild, mad Spark, that scarce ever lies at home: you know me, Madam, I suppose?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fidg.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Madam, in verity I must beg your pardon, I did belye the Gentleman, abominably belye him.

sp.speaker: La. Lands.
sp.p: What provok'd you to it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fidg.
sp.p: Truly, Ian, I contriv'd it, thinking it wou'd please your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: La. Lands.
sp.p: Ian, pray who is Ian?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fid.
sp.p: My Friend and his Footman.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: My Cousin, I am sure was always accounted a very modest, sober Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fidg.
sp.p: Modest! udsflesh, he has not his peer in the whole Town; by my fackings, he's a little too modest, that's his fault.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: I dare affirm he's truly noble, not in these straights of Fortune wou'd he quit his Honour, to be Great, or his Integrity to be Rich.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fidg.
sp.p: Or his Religion to be thought a Wit..

sp.speaker: La. Lands.
sp.p: Enough, Ladies, I am fully satisfi'd; only to his Love, if I have made any impression.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: That this moment you your self shall be judge of; he's coming, if▪ you please to retire you shall over-hear me sound his inclinations.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fidg.
sp.p: Aye, there he is, Heaven bless him, he's a sweet young man.

sp.speaker: La. Lands.
sp.p: Come with me Mrs. Fidget▪ Now Clerimont,
sp.l: If thy heart does with generous passion burn,
Than I with joy will love for love return.

div.stage: Enter the younger Clerimont, Belvoir and Jack.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I have brought him, Madam, but I am asham'd to say with what reluctancy, he flies even you, you the fair contriver of his Auspicious Fortunes.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: I am sure, I am asham'd to see you take such pains about a thing not worth your care.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: When the good suffer, the vertuous part of humane kind are all concern'd. When we suffer by our fate, and not our faults, Heaven always makes the tryal short, and shows an easie way for our deliverance.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: In vain you sooth me with your friendship; did you fully know me, you wou'd know, there scarce is left a room for hope.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p:
Suppose there is a Lady in love with you, surrounded thus as you are with your misfortunes; suppose her Chast, and Rich, and Fair, who tho
her eyes never yet encountred yours, by my description, doats upon a Character so singular and different from your wild Sex.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Were she as fair as Women wou'd be thought; as vertuous as they were of old, e're 'twas fashionable to be false; had she Wealth would satisfie the Vain, the Miser, the Ambitious; so far am I from once consenting to what your kindness has propos'd, I woud not to rid me of half my Sorrows, so much as see her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Ah, my friend! this must be some prepossession; you already are in Love.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: It is enough to say I am a fool, must search the world and know it better, e're I pretend to speak my thoughts. If, Madam, from my Brother ye can procure my Father's first design, I shall own my self eternally oblig'd, and trouble ye no more.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: I sigh to say it is not in my power, since you refuse the advantageous offers of the Lady's love.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Then all I beg, is that ye wou'd inquire for me no more. There is no warding the blows of Fate; the wretch that's doom'd unfortunate, no Arm of Power can save.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But you look thro despair. Believe me, friend, 'tis a false Glass, Fortune has a fairer Face to shew you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: That pleasing task be mine, Madam, you here the Gentleman is obstinate, but now, Sir, if you are not charm'd with this appearance, you have a relish different from the universal World.

div.stage: Re-enter Lady Landsworth, and Mrs. Fidget.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Ha! 'tis she! 'tis she! here let me fix, thus let me clasp my Bliss, thus for ever, secure my only valued treasure!

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis she, 'tis she, egad, and my Landlady too.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fid.
sp.p: Yes, Manners, your Landlady too:

sp.speaker: La. Lands.
sp.p: And dare you venture upon me, after the Alderman, the Colonel, and the Senator?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: My Eyes shou'd have contradicted all other Sences; sweet Innocence is writ in that dear face, and Vertue in her brightest Characters.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Vertuous and Great, the Charming Widow of Sir John Landsworth: Her Husband formerly, I believe you have seen. What cou'd you ask of Fate more, than to love and be belov'd by her?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: And have I been repining, when the bounteous Heavens were pouring such lavish Blessings down? Oh! my ravish'd Soul! My first, my only dear!

sp.speaker: La. Lands.
sp.p: 'Tis wondrous pretty, when Love's soft passion first invades our breast, it brings a thousand Charms, a thousand Joys, unknown before; but ah! too often in your Sex, rowling time, or some newer face, puts out the kindly flame, and the forsaken Fair is left to live, and languish on the kind Words which she will hear no more. What can secure me from such a Fate? Not even your present thoughts, for they may change.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p:
Never, my Charmer, never! To look on thee secures a heart like mine from roving: To hear thee talk, will fix me for ever in the Chains
of Love. But, oh! to have thee all; there words cannot aim, there breath is lost in extasie.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Here's a world of fine things; tho' I am a little of the Lady's mind, 'twill scarce hold out seven years.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: So, there's two in perfect happiness. I hope, Madam, you that were so Compassionate to others, will not your self be cruel, but reward my constant vows, nor let me longer sigh in vain.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Mr. Belvoir, I have allow'd you too long a favour'd Lover in honour to go back; we are as good as married already.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: No, my dear Angel, the greatest sweet's to come!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Ay, and the sowre too, that's the worst on't. Look, here's another happy Couple.

div.stage: Enter elder Clerimont, Mrs. Rich, Mr. Rich, Lucinda, Betty and Toby.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Well, Ladies, what d'ye think I have been doing since I went out? by my Stars! a world of business; and that's a thing I hate, writ a Billet-doux to the Beau in appearance; married the Beau in a disguise; given occasion for forty Stories, and fifty Lampoons, ha, ha, ha! I have done it all in a humour, by my Stars!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: E'en carry it on, Madam; never have a grave fit and repent, I say.

sp.speaker: El. Cler.
sp.p: Yes, faith, I'm sped, and all o'th' sudden; she's handsomer trath, than our Sh'riff's Daughter. How they'll stare, Toby, when she shows her paces thro' our Alley, to the great Pew. Brother Charles, how came you here? Well, I've gin the Writings into Cousin's hands: Udslids, does that pretty Lady belong to you? Why, this is a rare place for handsome Women, by my troth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Come, Sir, the Transformation has been Comical enough, but now I beg you to reassume your former Mein and Dress, and let me make as great a sacrifice to you, as the Lady made of you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Oh, dear Belvoir, say something to keep in my laugh, or I'm undone.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I dare not lift up my eyes, nor scarce open my lips to let my words out.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: I confess, my Gravity is put to the Test now.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Come, Mr. Clerimont, will ye hasten; pray dress immediately, because I expect Sir John this moment.

sp.speaker: El. Cler.
sp.p: Yes, fags, I'll dress, as soon as I can get my Cloaths made; and since I'm Wed, I'll bestow more money than I thought, by five pound.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Nay, now the humour's tiresome, here's only Friends.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, I shall break my Lace.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: What's the meaning of all this?

sp.speaker: La. Lands.
sp.p: The tittering Damsel behind ye, can tell.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Come, I wou'd not for a thousand pound Sir Jan shou'd find you thus; this is carrying the Jest too far. Speak to him, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Indeed, Madam, I fear it must go a little farther; for, to tell ye the plain truth, he has the Estate I mention'd, and is my Relation; but for the Accomplishments you expect, they are yet to learn, upon my word.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: How! I'm undone! What, no Conversation, no Judgment in Dress, no Mein, no Airs!

sp.speaker: El. Cler.
sp.p: Prithee, Cuz, what is that same Airs, d'ye see? I'd willingly please her, now I have her, d'ye see.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cle.
sp.p: Airs: Why, 'tis a foolish Word, used by those that do understand it, and those that do not; 'tis what's pretty, when Nature gives it; and what, when affected, spoils all that Nature gives beside.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Oh! I shall go mad. Is that an Object fit to please a Woman nice as I am?

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Come, Sister, a long Periwig, an Alamode Steenkirk, &c. has made a worse Face a perfect Beau e're now: Consider, he has some thousands a year.

sp.speaker: El. Cler.
sp.p: Ay, marry have I: Nay, udslid, I have a Title too; I value no more, d'ye see, killing a Man, than I do killing a Mouse; for I'd take up my Patent, be a Lord, and be try'd by my Peers.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Thy Peers! Where wou'dst find 'em?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Oh, my cursed Stars! First a Citizen's, and then a Country 'Squire's Wife. Ah! I shall never endure him, that's certain.

sp.speaker: El. Cler.
sp.p: Mid hap so, and mid hap ye may; I shan't cross ye mich. All the Hunting season I'll be in the Country: and you shall hunt Pleasures here in Town. Ge me a little of your money to pay my debt, and I won't trouble you, d'ye see.

sp.speaker: La. Lands.
sp.p: Well said, Mr. Bridegroom: Come, Madam, few Beaux wou'd be more Complaisant.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Madam, Sir John—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Mountains cover my shame! What shall I say now?

sp.speaker: La. Lands.
sp.p: Say! laugh at him, as all the World ought.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: Believe me, Madam, ye have made the better choice.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: A thousand times.

div.stage: Enter Sir John, and Mrs. Trickwell.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trick.
sp.p: You bring me here to see you Triumph, I can never believe it; you have some trick put upon you, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Have I not her own Note, that spight of her Jealousies, and her Brother's Tyranny, she will this day be married.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trick.
sp.p: She does not say to you. Ha! What a World of Company is here?

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: The Brother, and the young Gipsie his Daughter: I'll be gone.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Nay, no retreating, Sir John, you must, at least, wish the Lady joy.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Sha, my design's broke, my Plots spoiled, can I Triumph at his defeat, and show that awkard figure?

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Madam, your Summons brought me hither, I hop'd to Joys.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: I hate you, and all mankind.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: So do I; ye sham Lord, ye brag, ye bounce ye—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Enough, good Miss. Sir John, I perceive you must search for new Gallantries, here the Ladies are provided for, except this little one, who seems to have no inclination.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Pax take ye all; they were fond, I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Come, ye young Coquette, your Education shall be alter'd, I assure ye, 'tis e'en high time.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Trick.
sp.p: Well, I believe my booty with yonder fantastical Lady is at an end, so I'll steal off unobserv'd.

sp.speaker: La. Bas.
sp.p: Where is this Villain, This false, ungrateful Villain?

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: So; another outcry?

sp.speaker: La. Bas.
sp.p: Yes, Traytor, and a just one: Know all, this was but a Servant in Sir John Roverhead's Family; I drest him in these borrow'd honours, knowing Sir John never came to Town. I taught him the Modes and Manners here, and he has rewarded me with Inconstancy.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Hold, hold; not so fast. How came you to be the Honourable, the Lady Basset: I think 'twas I dubb'd ye. As I take it, ye were but the cast Mistress of Sir Francis Basset, when I found ye.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: See, Sister, how the Quality you were fond of, expose one an other.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: And seeing this, be reconcil'd to your new Spouse, who is of a noble Family, and I promise to introduce ye to Persons of Merit and Honour.

sp.speaker: La. Lands.
sp.p: We shall all be fond of ye, for, of your self, you are Charming and Sensible: 'Tis only these Wretches have render'd ye ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Come, give him your hand, 'tis a gentle punishment for so much vanity.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Well, since my malicious Stars have thus decreed it; but, d'ye hear, I expect to have your Estate in my power, and that same Title you talk off look'd into.

sp.speaker: El. Cler.
sp.p: ●●ackings and so you shall; but must not I have your fine parson in my power too? ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Has the Thing sence enough to be in Love?

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Now, I hope, all's well, and I have prevail'd with my Landlady to give ye a Song.

sp.speaker: La. Lands.
sp.p: Do, good Mrs. Fidget?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fid.
sp.p: Any thing to divert ye.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: And ad●d, after that, I'll give 'em a donce.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Well sed, honest Toby.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Rich.
sp.p: Sir Jan, will ye participate our diversion, or employ your time in reconciling your self to this inraged Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Joh.
sp.p: Shame, Disappointment and Disreputation light upon you all; wou'd all the whole Sex were upon Salisbury Plain, and their rigging on fire about their Ears.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Cler.
sp.p: And that's the dreadful Curse of a defeated Beau. Follow, Madam, and put him in a better humour.

sp.speaker: La. Bas.
sp.p: Hang him, as I wou'd my self, you, and all the World.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: A fair riddance.

sp.speaker: Cler.
sp.p: Now the Song, and then the Dance.

sp.speaker: Mr. Rich.
sp.p: Now, Sister, and Daughter, to you I chiefly speak, let this days Adventure make ye for ever cautious of your Conversation; you see how near these pretenders to Quality had brought you to ruin: The truly Great are of a quite different Character.
sp.l: The Glory of the World our British Nobles are,
The Ladies too Renown'd, and Chast and fair:
But to our Citizens, Augusta's Sons,
The Conquering Wealth of both the India's runs;
Tho' less in Name, of greater Power by far,
Honours alone, but empty Scutcheons are;
Mixt with their Coin, the Title sweetly sounds,
No such Allay as Twenty Thousand Pounds.
